fields.super_short_description: A clean, crisp and green oolong tea
fields.body_text:
Light, refreshing and low in caffeine, Iron Buddha (tie guan yin) is the perfect start to your healthy lifestyle.

It's a classic pure and green Chinese Oolong tea, grown in the high mountains of Anxi County in Fujian and has a special xiang suan taste, which refreshes the palette and tingles the tastebuds. It's also great as an appetiser or with snacks.
fields.image_2_caption: Iron Buddha tea has sumptuous shades of light and dark green, and a light fragrance when dry. These leaves are picked fresh, cleaned and then dried, which gives them their stunning colour.
fields.image_5_caption: All our tea is delivered freeze-wrapped for freshness in resealable foil packaging, so you get a locked in fresh taste with every cup.
fields.body_text_en:
Light, refreshing and low in caffeine, Iron Buddha (tie guan yin) is the perfect start to your healthy lifestyle.

It's a classic pure and green Chinese Oolong tea, grown in the high mountains of Anxi County in Fujian and has a special xiang suan taste, which refreshes the palette and tingles the tastebuds. It's also great as an appetiser or with snacks.
fields.meta_title: Iron Buddha Oolong Tea (tie guan yin)
fields.long_name: Iron Buddha Green Oolong Tea 铁观音
fields.image_4_caption: The Iron Buddha tea leaves, after being brewed. You can see the full leaves have unfurled and still retain their deep green hue - a sign of a great tea!
fields.long_description:
Iron Buddha (tie guan yin) is grown in the mountainous areas of Anxi County in southern China. It's an 'oolong' tea (wu long), which means it is part of a family of teas which can be found in Fujian, Guang Dong and Taiwan provinces. Oolong teas are not always green - in fact, our red tea The Big Red is also an oolong tea.

Iron Buddha is hugely popular in China, with a refined taste that is ideal for relaxing with friends or impressing important visitors. For tea beginners, it's the perfect starter tea as it really defines what green tea should look, smell and taste like. This variety of Iron Buddha is slightly unique, with a crisp and refreshing edge that typical Iron Buddha teas don't share. The Chinese call this taste tuo suan or xiang suan.
fields.extra_info:
Tasting notes

This variety has a sweeter, crisper taste than usual. Brew it with approx. 90 degrees water, around 4-7g for each person. You should taste a little cleansing/tingling sensation around your palette as you drink it.
Read full instructions »
See how Iron Buddha is made [PHOTOS]

fields.super_short_description: A rich and red oolong tea
fields.body_text:
Rich, red and full-bodied, The Big Red (da hong pao) is the ideal tea if you like a bit of bite to your brew.

It's grown in the Wuyi Mountains of Fujian, and is an Oolong tea with a natural smokey taste and hints of cinnamon. It's great first thing in the morning, and is one of our most popular teas.
fields.image_2_caption: The Big Red leaves are deep brown in colour, light and brittle. They have an earthy fragrance, and can be steeped many times, so a single pot can last all day!
fields.image_5_caption: All our tea is delivered freeze-wrapped for freshness in resealable foil packaging, so you get a locked in fresh taste with every cup.
fields.meta_title: The Big Red tea (da hong pao) - Chinese red oolong tea
fields.long_name: The Big Red Oolong Tea 大红袍
fields.image_4_caption: Once infused in water, the Big Red tea leaves become softer and flexible, and can be brewed many times for a long-lasting cup.
fields.long_description:
The Big Red is grown in the Wuyi Shan (Wuyi mountain) area of the Fujian Province. It's a member of the 'oolong' tea family (wu long) like one of our other teas, Iron Buddha.

The Big Red has a complicated history - the original tea plant is under strict guard and is a national treasure in China. It yields only about 250g a year, and is reserved for high politicians or state visitors (the Queen reportedly got a cup when she visited China in 1986!). Luckily for us, enterprising thieves many years ago stole shoots from the plant and now The Big Red is cultivated across the Fujian province.
fields.extra_info:
Tasting notes

This tea has a beautiful taste, but don't kill it with over-brewing! Try slightly off-the-boil water for just 30-40 seconds and you'll uncover the deeper flavours without the bitterness.
Read full instructions »
fields.meta_description: A rich and red Oolong tea, great in the mornings. This tea comes from the mountains of southern China and is ideal for people who like a bite to their brew.
fields.image_3_caption: A cup of The Big Red has a rich red colour and a strong flavour. If you like your tea with a bite, brew it with boiling water for 1-2 minutes.
fields.description: A rich and red Oolong tea, great in the mornings. This tea comes from the mountains of southern China and is ideal for people who like a bite to their brew.
fields.name: The Big Red

fields.super_short_description: A fragrant and bright scented green tea
fields.body_text:
Stunningly fragrant Jasmine scented green tea, this tea is hand-made by rolling fresh green tea leaves together with natural jasmine flowers.

The sweet jasmine flavour infuses the tea leaves with a taste guaranteed to wow you and your guests. If you're giving tea as a gift, this is a sure-fire winner.
fields.image_2_caption: Our Jasmine Pearls are hand-rolled into tiny balls - steep in boiling water for just a minute and watch them expand and release their flavour.
fields.image_5_caption: All our tea is delivered freeze-wrapped for freshness in resealable foil packaging, so you get a locked in fresh taste with every cup.
fields.long_name: Jasmine Pearls Scented Green Tea 茉莉花龙珠
fields.image_4_caption: The brewed Jasmine Pearl tea-leaves. They still retain a gorgeous green colour, and are slightly thinner than other tea leaves.
fields.long_description:
Jasmine Pearls are grown and processed in Fuzhou, our home. The tea leaves are wrapped tightly into balls along with Jasmine flowers, slowly absorbing their scent. Jasmine tea is well known, ubiquitous in many Chinese restaurants, and many different grades exist. The two main factors affecting taste are the quality of the original green tea leaves, and how the scent is added.

Our Jasmine Pearls are high grade, using young tea leaves as the base, and only natural Jasmine flowers (ie. no oils are used to enhance the fragrance). The result is a delicate and natural fragrance bursting from each brew, and a soft, smooth tea liquid.
fields.extra_info:
Tasting notes

There's a dominant floral Jasmine fragrance, but underneath there are hints of berries and grass, a fruit-edge which comes out with a gentler brew. Use 80 degree water for 1 minute for best results.
Read full instructions »
fields.meta_description: Delicious Jasmine Pearls scented green tea direct from the farm in Fuzhou - buy with confidence from one of the only independent tea companies actually based in China.
fields.image_3_caption: Jasmine Pearl tea has a light auburn colour - for best results, don't brew it for too long and aim for a crystal and light tone.
fields.description: Delicious Jasmine scented green tea - the unbelievably fragrant hand-rolled tea leaves, infused using natural Jasmine flowers, are the perfect treat for you or a friend.
fields.name: Jasmine Pearls

fields.super_short_description: A starter pack of three Chinese teas
fields.body_text:
Three superb teas to start your journey into Chinese tea. This simple beginners pack contains three of our most popular Chinese teas: Iron Buddha, Jasmine Pearls, and The Big Red.

Each tea represents a unique flavour and variety of Chinese tea and as well as being a great gift, is the ideal way to explore your favourite tastes.
fields.image_2_caption: Our delicious green oolong Iron Buddha is included in the sampler pack
fields.image_4_caption: Our smokey Big Red dark oolong tea is included in the sample pack
fields.long_description: This sampler pack contains each of our three fantastic Chinese teas - Iron Buddha a classic and crisp green oolong; The Big Red a dark and smokey red oolong; and Jasmine Pearls. Each has a distinct taste, so this is perfect for finding out which suits you. Each is packaged in a high quality and durable presentation tin.
fields.extra_info:
Tasting notes

All of these teas come from the same plant, despite how it may appear. As you try them, learn to taste not just the differences, but also the common theme running through them - that is the real taste of tea.
fields.meta_description: Start your Chinese tea journey with our simple starter pack. It contains tasters of our three most popular teas, and is a great way to experience three unique flavours of naturally made tea.
fields.image_3_caption: Our fragrant Jasmine Pearls green tea is included in the sampler pack
fields.description: Start your Chinese tea journey with our simple starter pack. It contains tasters of our three most popular teas, and is a great way to experience three unique flavours of naturally made tea.
fields.name: Beginners Pack

fields.super_short_description: Pine smoked Chinese red tea
fields.body_text:
The world-famous pinewood-smoked red tea, Lapsang Souchong (zheng shan xiao zhong) is a 'love-it-or-hate-it' tea.

Produced in the Wuyi Mountains of Fujian, we're sure you'll love it for it's laid-back smokey taste and soothing aroma that's just perfect for those lazy Sunday mornings. One of our customers calls it 'campfire tea' and the name is catching on...
fields.long_name: Lapsang Souchong Red Tea 正山小种
fields.long_description:
Lapsang souchong (zhēng shān xiǎo zhǒng in Chinese) is a tea native to Wuyi Mountain in Fujian. It has a distinctive woody taste, given by the unique way it is dried over smoking pinewood, and is one of the best soothing morning teas available.

It's a fully oxidised black tea, meaning it lasts well and keeps its flavour over time. Brewing is simple and easy - you can use boiling water and infuse for 30-60 seconds to release the full flavour. The brewed leaves have a woody-red colour, reminiscent of the pinewood it is smoked over. Most Lapsang commercially sold in teabags are ground and powdered into fine dust. The Lapsang we sell is whole-leaf and high-grade, direct from farms on Wuyi Mountain near our home.
fields.extra_info:
Tasting notes

The perennial 'bonfire' tea is known for its smokey head - but underneath the surface there are other tastes. Nuts and winter fruits appear with a lighter brew. Try brewing with boiling water, and then ease off on the temperature.
Read full instructions »
fields.meta_description: A pinewood-smoked red tea from the Wuyi Mountains. Well-loved around the world, it has a delicious aroma and soft, relaxing fragrance   perfect on those lazy Sunday mornings.
fields.description: A pinewood-smoked red tea from the Wuyi Mountains. Well-loved around the world, it has a delicious aroma and soft, relaxing fragrance perfect on those lazy Sunday mornings.
fields.name: Lapsang Souchong

fields.super_short_description: Charcoal roasted oolong tea.
fields.body_text:
A charcoal-roasted dark Oolong tea, the affectionately named Old Iron (lao tie) falls halfway between a green and red Oolong.

The flavour carries the clarity and pure taste of a green Oolong, but with the more subtle deep roasted tones of a red. Often ignored even in China, nevertheless this tea is one of our favourite brews to date and a great everyday drink.
fields.meta_title: Old Iron Roasted Oolong Chinese Tea
fields.long_name: Old Iron Charcoal Roasted Tea 老铁
fields.long_description:
Old Iron Roasted Oolong is a semi-roasted green oolong tea from Anxi in the Fujian Province. It sits between green and red oolongs, with the deep, rich flavours of a red tea, but the clarity and smooth taste of a tie guan yin.

The name is a monicker given due to the way it is made. When green oolongs like Iron Buddha reach the end of their shelf life, they can be roasted again to extend their life. Over the years, tea experts found that re-roasted teas had a unique and appealing taste. Our Old Iron has a clear and complex taste, without the buttery overtones of a green oolong, and carrying the woody taste common in red or black teas.
fields.extra_info:
Tasting notes

You can treat this just like the Iron Buddha - 4-7g of tea for each cup (that's a big three-finger pinch) and brew it with 90 degree water. The taste will really come out after the 2nd or 3rd brew, so be patient!
Read full instructions »
fields.meta_description: A charcoal roasted Oolong tea, this tea carries the clear notes of a green Oolong, with the full-bodied taste of a red.
fields.description: A charcoal roasted Oolong tea, this tea carries the clear notes of a green Oolong, with the full-bodied taste of a red.
fields.name: Old Iron

fields.super_short_description: Sweet, fruity Chinese red tea.
fields.body_text:
A naturally sweet and fruity red tea, Jin Jun Mei (sometimes called Golden Eyebrow) is the perfect tea for the sweet-tooths out there.

Grown in the Wuyi Mountains of Fujian, it has a plummy and well rounded taste and naturally sweet edge. It's quickly become one of China's most popular teas in recent years, and with good reason.
fields.long_name: Jin Jun Mei Red Tea 金骏眉
fields.long_description:
Jin Jun Mei is a fully oxidised black tea from the Wuyi Mountain area of Fujian. It's actually a relatively 'new' tea, having been created just a few years ago. However it's caught on fast and quickly become one of the most popular tea gifts given in China.

The tea is made using two small shoots from each stem of the tea plant. When we appreciate many other types of tea, we look for large and full leaves - however with Jin Jun Mei the smaller and thinner the dried tea leaves, the better. The taste of a good Jin Jun Mei should be clean and clear, with fruity overtones and the deep smokey undertone shared by all Wuyi teas. As with all black teas, it can be brewed with near boiling water and rebrewed 3-5 times.
fields.extra_info:
Tasting notes

Jin Jun Mei is a rewarding tea. It carries undertones of red dates and plums, with a syrupy richness that sweet-toothed tea drinkers will appreciate. Take it easy temperature-wise - 90 degrees is enough.
Read brewing instructions »
fields.meta_description: A naturally fruity-sweet red tea from the Wuyi Mountains. It has a distinct, plummy taste and has become one of the most popular teas in China today.
fields.description: A naturally fruity-sweet red tea from the Wuyi Mountains. It has a distinct, plummy taste and has become one of the most popular teas in China today.
fields.name: Jin Jun Mei

fields.super_short_description: Light and natural white tea.
fields.body_text:
Made from only tender young tea-shoots, Silver Needle (yin zhen) tea has a fresh taste as close as you'll get to plucking the tea-leaves yourself.

The taste is lighter and more vegetal than other green teas, and because of the strict use of only young shoots and careful wilting under the sun, demand is always high.
fields.long_name: Silver Needle White Tea 银针白茶
fields.long_description:
Silver Needle (yin zhen) is a renowned white tea grown in Ning De in the north of the Fujian Province. It's lightly oxidised, and undergoes very little processing compared to other green or red teas. Only the youngest tea-shoots are used to make the tea, hence why this tea is so highly valued.

The taste is very light and summery, with very little edge or bitterness. Freshly picked tea leaves actually carry very little taste or fragrance, but the short and simple processing applied to Silver Needle leaves brings out a delicate floral taste and subtle hint of chlorophyll which many aficionados regard as the 'purest' tea taste.
fields.extra_info:
Tasting notes

This tea is very delicate, so make sure you keep it sealed and in the fridge. Use 80 degrees water for between 30-50s - a good rule of thumb is leave your boiled water for 3 minutes before pouring.
Read full instructions »
fields.meta_description: A light and natural white tea made with only the most tender and youngest tea-leaves available.
fields.description: A light and natural white tea made with only the most tender and youngest tea-leaves available.
fields.name: Silver Needle

fields.super_short_description: A sample of three of our finest teas
fields.body_text:
Sample three of the most sought-after teas in China - Iron Buddha, Jin Jun Mei and Silver Needle, all grown and produced in Fujian, China.

Each of these teas is the pinnacle of its genre, offering distinct tastes ranging from clean and pure white tea, rich and smooth Oolong, to punchy and naturally sweet black tea.
fields.extra_info:
Tasting notes

As you taste these three fine teas, take in all aspects of the brew - look at the colour of the liquid, the leaves before and after brewing, and the range of tastes, from the heavily roasted Jin Jun Mei right up to the very lightly processed Silver Needle.
fields.meta_description: Sample three of our finest Chinese teas, representing the most unique and sought-after tastes among tea aficionados.
fields.description: Sample three of our finest Chinese teas, representing the most unique and sought-after tastes among tea aficionados.
fields.name: Fine Tea Taster

fields.super_short_description: Sample three exceptional green teas.
fields.body_text:
Three superb, lightly processed and natural green teas, offering a range of natural green tea tastes you wouldn't believe possible.

It's a shame that when most of us think of green tea, we think of tasteless teabags - this selection of our finest Iron Buddha, Silver Needle and Jasmine Pearls tea is here to reverse that trend.
fields.extra_info:
Tasting notes

Each of these green teas has undergone very little processing and roasting, and all keep some of the natural, 'vegetal' taste of the raw tea leaf. As you're tasting them, pay attention not just to the differences but the similarities.
fields.meta_description: A selection of three lightly processed and natural green teas, showing the depth of tastes available to Chinese tea drinkers.
fields.description: A selection of three lightly processed and natural green teas, showing the depth of tastes available to Chinese tea drinkers.
fields.name: Green Tea Taster

fields.super_short_description: Taste three traditional oolong teas
fields.body_text:
Taste the full range of Oolong tea, from green to red, and enjoy the subtle differences in flavour through each stage of oolong processing.

Together these three teas show the breadth and depth of Oolong teas, from a lightly oxidised Iron Buddha, a medium-charcoal-roasted Old Iron, and a deep-roasted red Big Red tea.
fields.extra_info:
Tasting notes

Oolong teas are semi-oxidised, but the taste varies depending on how long the roasting goes on. Start with the Iron Buddha, then the Old Iron, and finish with the Big Red to see how the deeper flavours emerge when a tea is roasted for longer.
fields.meta_description: Explore the range of Oolong flavours with these three exceptional teas, ranging from light and medium roast green Oolongs up to a dark roasted, full-bodied red tea.
fields.description: Explore the range of Oolong flavours with these three exceptional teas, ranging from light and medium roast green Oolongs up to a dark roasted, full-bodied red tea.
fields.name: Oolong Tea Taster

fields.super_short_description: Three red teas from the Wuyi Mountains.
fields.body_text:
Three teas, three unique tastes, all from one region. Grown in the Wuyi Mountains within a few kilometres, each offers subtly different layers of natural fruit, charcoal and pinewood tastes.

As you taste this Big Red, Jin Jun Mei and Lapsang Souchong taster pack, you'll see how even small differences in how tea is picked and processed can produce vast variations in taste.
fields.extra_info:
Tasting notes

For any red or black tea, you can add slightly hotter water and it brings out an edgier brew which many prefer. But try easing back on the temperature, and compare the softer, fruitier tastes that come out with 80 or 90 degree water.
fields.meta_description: Three teas, three unique tastes, all from the same Wuyi Mountain area of Fujian. Try these teas and see how the subtle differences in processing and harvesting methods can produce huge variation of tastes.
fields.description: Three teas, three unique tastes, all from the same Wuyi Mountain area of Fujian. Try these teas and see how the subtle differences in processing and harvesting methods can produce huge variation of tastes.
fields.name: Red Tea Taster

fields.super_short_description: Three unique roasted Chinese teas
fields.body_text:
Explore the different tastes of roasted Chinese teas. Yes, tea is roasted! But different methods produce unique tastes, even when the tea comes from the same plant.

This sample pack contains samples of our fine Jin Jun Mei and Lapsang Souchong from the Wuyi Mountain area and our Charcoal Roasted Old Iron oolong tea from Anxi County.
fields.extra_info:
Tasting notes

The purpose of this sampler is to let you see how different roasting materials affect the taste. Lapsang is smoked over pinewood, our Old Iron is roasted over natural charcoal, and Jin Jun Mei is produced in a similar way to Lapsang Souchong but without the pinewood stage.
fields.meta_description: Discover the differences between three different roasted Chinese teas. All three teas in this sample come from the same plant, and yet the preparation methods make all the difference to the taste in your cup.
fields.description: Discover the differences between three different roasted Chinese teas. All three teas in this sample come from the same plant, and yet the preparation methods make all the difference to the taste in your cup.
fields.name: Roasted Tea Taster

fields.super_short_description: A perfect wide-based glass tea cup
fields.body_text:
This beautiful and practical glass tea cup sits perfectly on your desk or table, and is an elegant companion for your Chinese teas.

It has an attractive and modern wide-base design, so it's great for serving tea in style whether on your desk at work or with friends. We use this cup every day as it holds just the right amount, and lets you appreciate the pure colour of your freshly brewed tea. Holds approx. 200ml.
fields.meta_description: A beautiful and practical glass teacup perfect for drinking Chinese teas. Thin walled and wide based design mean it sits comfortably on your desk and holds just enough tea for one sitting.
fields.description: A beautiful yet practical glass teacup perfect for drinking Chinese teas. Thin walled and wide based design mean it sits comfortably on your desk and holds just enough tea for one sitting.
fields.name: Wide-base teacup

fields.super_short_description: Sturdy and stylish double-walled mug.
fields.body_text:
This huge glass tea mug holds an entire pot of tea so it's great at your desk or if you really enjoy your tea in buckets.

Plus, the double-walled glass construction means you can appreciate the colour and hue of your fresh loose-leaf tea while it stays warm (and your hands don't get scalded by the boiling water!). Holds approx. 600ml
fields.meta_description: Durable and sturdy, this double-walled glass mug holds a whole pot of tea, and it's layered-glass design means it will keep your tea nice and warm without scalding your hands!
fields.description: Durable and sturdy, this double-walled glass mug holds a whole pot of tea, and it's layered-glass design means it will keep your tea nice and warm without scalding your hands!
fields.name: Double Walled Tea Mug

fields.super_short_description: A stylish glass teapot with built-in infuser
fields.body_text:
Brew your tea to perfection using this glass infuser teapot. Its solid glass design and built-in infuser are perfect for beautiful and fast brewing of the perfect cuppa.

Simply place your loose-leaf tea in the removable glass infuser basket, and add hot water, and then watch your tea expand and unfurl, infusing your brew with their delicate taste. Holds approx. 600ml.

Simply place your loose-leaf tea in the removable glass infuser basket, and add hot water, and then watch your tea expand and unfurl, infusing your brew with their delicate taste. Holds approx. 600ml.

fields.super_short_description: Double-walled glass sipping cups.
fields.body_text:
Taste your tea the traditional way using these miniature glass sipping cups.

They hold a perfect three sips of tea, just enough to appreciate the flavour of your loose-leaf teas, and their double-walled construction is stylish, keeps your tea hot, and also stops your fingers getting scalded by the hot water.

Taste your tea the traditional way using these miniature glass sipping cups.

They hold a perfect three sips of tea, just enough to appreciate the flavour of your loose-leaf teas, and their double-walled construction is stylish, keeps your tea hot, and also stops your fingers getting scalded by the hot water.

fields.super_short_description: Glass storage pots perfect for your fresh teas.
fields.body_text:
Store your teas in style - these glass and cork storage pots are perfect for keeping your tea fresh as the day they were picked.

Teas can degrade quickly if you don't store them properly, so these storage pots make the perfect companion for your teas. A cork lid seals in the fresh taste, and it's easy to see when you're running low through the clear glass walls.

fields.super_short_description: An incredible, unique red Jasmine tea.
fields.body_text:
Red Jasmine is a tea taste revolution - the deep, earthy tones of red tea combined with a sweet Jasmine fragrance.

Traditionally, only green tea leaves couuld hold the delicate Jasmine flower fragrance - until now. Red Jasmine Tea is made using a recently discovered method, and is one of the 'holy grails' of tea-tasting. We're proud to be the first UK company to sell this incredible tea, and it's our new favourite brew!
fields.long_description:
Red Jasmine tea is the answer to an age old problem for Jasmine tea enthusiasts - how to produce a tea that blends a natural Jasmine scent with the deep tones of red teas? While green teas accept the Jasmine flavour quite easily, red teas have two problems - they either won't absorb the fragrance, or the fragrance doesn't last as the tea is re-brewed.

A new and fairly secretive technique has been developed that solves these problems, and the result is our Jasmine Red tea. Because the technique is new, and requires considerable skill, this is one of the most expensive teas we sell. It is grown and produced in Fuzhou, Fujian Province.
fields.extra_info:
Tasting notes

This is a fantastic tasting tea, and tastes best when brewed lightly for around 30-40 seconds with just off-the-boil water. It'll bring out the natural sweet and floral fragrance and avoid any dry or bitter tastes that result from stewing the tea.
fields.meta_description: A unique Jasmine tea that uses red tea rather than green tea as a base - we're the only tea retailer selling this incredible tasting tea!
fields.description: A unique Jasmine tea that uses red tea rather than green tea as a base - we're the only tea retailer selling this incredible tasting tea!
fields.name: Jasmine Red

fields.super_short_description: A strong green oolong, grown in the birthplace of Chinese White Crane kung fu.
fields.body_text:
Buddha's Hand is a green oolong tea grown in the birthplace of White Crane kung fu. We've got limited stocks, so use your chi and order it quickly!

This tea has a superb rich, buttery taste, and also has the highest tannin content of any oolong tea. It's one reason why the locals believe it to be soothing to the digestive system.
fields.long_description: This tea was picked in April 2012 in Yong Chun, Fujian Province.
fields.extra_info:
Tasting notes

This fo shou tea has quite a strong taste, and that's how the Yong Chun locals like it. You can either try to brew it light (10-20 seconds, 90 degree water) or just embrace the tannins and natural chlorophyll taste by brewing for 30-40 seconds with just off the boil water.
fields.description: A strong green oolong, grown in the birthplace of Chinese White Crane kung fu.
fields.name: Buddha's Hand

fields.super_short_description: The most desired green Chinese tea from Hangzhou, Zhe Jiang.
fields.body_text:
Every spring, tea lovers go weak at the knees for Long Jing tea. Why? Because it represents a fresh, natural taste that many see as the peak of Chinese tea culture.

The leaves are pressed into flat, green dagger shapes and dried. Once brewed they open up revealing soft and delicate tea shoots and a fragrance reminscent of cut-grass on a summers day.
fields.body_text_en:
Every spring, tea lovers go weak at the knees for Long Jing tea. Why? Because it represents a fresh, natural taste that many see as the peak of Chinese tea culture.

The leaves are pressed into flat, green dagger shapes and dried. Once brewed they open up revealing soft and delicate tea shoots and a fragrance reminscent of cut-grass on a summers day.
fields.long_description_de:
Long Jing Tee (龙井茶, im Westen auch als Drachenbrunnen Tee oder Dragon Well bekannt) ist einer von Chinas berühmtesten Teesorten. Tee-Aficionados und Spekulanten haben die Preise für diesen traditionell in Hangzhou angebauten Tee sind in den letzten Jahren in die Höhe getrieben, ein halbes Kilo der ersten Frühlingspflückung (first flush) kann da auch schonmal mehr als 20.000€ kosten !

Unser Long Jing Tee wird von einem der bekanntesten Anbauern in Zhu Ji City, Hangzhou angebaut und verarbeit und ist vor dem Ming Qing Fest (April 2012) gepfückt worden, .
fields.description_de: Ein grüner Klassiker aus Hangzhou, dieser vor dem Qing Ming Fest gepflückter Tee hat ein süβen, grasigen Duft und ergibt einen natürlich grünen Aufguss.
fields.long_description:
Long Jing tea (龙井茶, also called Dragon Well in the West) is one of China's most famous teas. Traditionally grown in Hangzhou in Zhe Jiang Province, in recent years tea aficionados and speculators have pushed prices up to record levels, sometimes paying in excess of £18,000 a half kilo for the first flushes!

Our Long Jing tea is grown and processed by one of the top ten tea growers in Zhu Ji City, Hangzhou, and was picked pre-Ming Qing, April 2012.
fields.extra_info:
Tasting notes

Long Jing is made with the soft tea shoots, so you need to treat it delicately. Use approx. 80 degree water (leave the kettle to sit for 2 minutes before pouring) and you don't need too much tea; around 3g (a medium pinch) will do. Often the 3rd brew is the best, so remember to rebrew your leaves!
fields.long_description_en:
Long Jing tea (龙井茶, also called Dragon Well in the West) is one of China's most famous teas. Traditionally grown in Hangzhou in Zhe Jiang Province, in recent years tea aficionados and speculators have pushed prices up to record levels, sometimes paying in excess of £18,000 a half kilo for the first flushes!

Our Long Jing tea is grown and processed by one of the top ten tea growers in Zhu Ji City, Hangzhou, and was picked pre-Ming Qing, April 2012.
fields.extra_info_en:
Tasting notes

Long Jing is made with the soft tea shoots, so you need to treat it delicately. Use approx. 80 degree water (leave the kettle to sit for 2 minutes before pouring) and you don't need too much tea; around 3g (a medium pinch) will do. Often the 3rd brew is the best, so remember to rebrew your leaves!
fields.super_short_description_de: Der begehrteste grüne Tee aus Hangzhou, Zhejiang.
fields.super_short_description_en: The most desired green Chinese tea from Hangzhou, Zhe Jiang.
fields.description: The classic green tea from Hangzhou, this pre-Qing Ming festival tea has a sweet, grassy fragrance and a naturally green liquid.
fields.description_en: The classic green tea from Hangzhou, this pre-Qing Ming festival tea has a sweet, grassy fragrance and a naturally green liquid.
fields.body_text_de:
Jeden Frühling gehen Teelieber vor dem Long Jing Tee auf die Knie. Warum? Weil er einen frischen, natürlichen Geschmack repräsentiert, der für viele der Gipfel chinesischer Teekultur darstellt.

Die Teeblätter werden gepresst und erhalten eine Dolch-ähnliche Form, anschlieβend werden sie getrocknet. Beim Brühen öffnen sich die Blätter und offenbaren einen zarten Duft, der an frisch-gemähtes Gras an einem Sommertag erinnert.
fields.extra_info_de:
Hinweise für die Zubereitung

Da der Long Jing von jungen Teetrieben hergestellt wird, muss mit ihm behutsam umgegangen werden. Empfohlene Wassertemperatur liegt bei 80 Grad (nach dem Kochen den Kessel für 2 Min stehen lassen und dann einschütten), 3 g Tee (mittelgroβe Prise) reichen vollkommen. Der 3. Aufguss ist oft der besser, also nicht vergessen den Tee mehrmals aufzubrühen!
fields.name: Long Jing

fields.super_short_description: Citrus tones, exceptional aroma - a genuinely incredible tea.
fields.body_text:
An incredibly vibrant tea with spicy, citrus undertones. We were blown away by the complexity and clarity of this tea when we first tried it.

Hailing from the Wu Dong Mountains of Guang Dong Province in southern China, this tea is part-oxidised offering light, brittle and exceptionally colourful leaves.
fields.extra_info:
Tasting notes

A big three-finger pinch, slightly off-the-boil water and around 1 minute brewing time will be perfect. Initially the aroma will slightly overpower the taste on your tongue, but by the 2nd or 3rd brew, you should taste citrus, and also a sweet aftertaste on the sides of your mouth.
fields.description: With a light yet heady aroma and deep citrus tones, this Dan Cong Oolong tea from Wu Dong Mountain is an incredible addition to your teapot.
fields.name: Phoenix Dan Cong

fields.super_short_description: A modern teapot perfect for the office.
fields.body_text:
Presenting The Tea Shaker - a breakthrough in home tea brewing.The Tea Shaker means you can now make great tasting loose leaf tea in minutes- quicker than a cup of coffee.

Gone are the days of messy inconvenient straining and pouring; the Tea Shaker takes care of it all. Plus, our cutting edge new design means you can now make tea hassle free at home or out and about. It's safe, secure, and super easy.
fields.body_text_en:
Presenting The Tea Shaker - a breakthrough in home tea brewing.The Tea Shaker means you can now make great tasting loose leaf tea in minutes- quicker than a cup of coffee.

Gone are the days of messy inconvenient straining and pouring; the Tea Shaker takes care of it all. Plus, our cutting edge new design means you can now make tea hassle free at home or out and about. It's safe, secure, and super easy.
fields.long_description_de:
Der Tee Shaker ist die ideale Reise-Teekanne - einfach, handlich, langlebig und perfekt abgedichtet. So geht's:

(1)Die Teeblätter oben einfüllen. (2) Oben Wasser hinzugeben. (3) Schütteln bis der Aufguss nach unten gesunken ist (4) Umdrehen und Deckel öffnen. (5) Den Tee trinken!
fields.description_de: Mit dem Tee Shaker sauber und unkompliziert zur perfekten Tasse Tee - die moderne Teekanne zum Schütteln.
fields.long_description:
The Tea Shaker is the perfect travel teapot - it's simple, small, durable and doesn't leak or leave a watery mess in your office or lap. Here's how you use it:

(1) Put your tea in the top. (2) Add water in the top. (3) Shake side to side until the tea liquid has sunk to the bottom. (4) Turn it upside down and unscrew the lid. (5) Drink your tea!
fields.extra_info:
Safety

The Tea Shaker is safe and simple to use, but we do not recommend allowing small children to handle boiling water. Similarly, please empty your Tea Shaker of liquid before putting it in a bag or suitcase - it is not designed to store liquids in transit!

fields.description: Simple, clean and sleek, the Tea Shaker is a modern teapot that is easy to use and makes a perfect cup each time with no mess and no fuss.
fields.description_en: Simple, clean and sleek, the Tea Shaker is a modern teapot that is easy to use and makes a perfect cup each time with no mess and no fuss.
fields.body_text_de:
Siehe da, der Tee Shaker - die Innovation für den unkomplizierten Teeaufguss Mit dem Tee Shaker können Sie buchstäblich im Handumdrehen eine herrlich frische Tasse Tee aufbrühen.

Mit dem Tee Shaker gehören die Tage umständlichen Filterns und Umgieβens der Vergangenheit. Das innovative Design erlaubt es Ihnen zu Hause oder unterwegs mühelos Tee zuzubereiten. Schnell, Einfach und ohne Kleckern.
fields.extra_info_de:
Sicherheit

Der Tee Shaker ist sicher und einfach in der Handhabung, doch es ratsam Kinder von heiβem Wasser fernzuhalten. Auβerdem sollte der Tee Shaker entleert werden bevor er in eine Tasche oder Koffer gepackt wird - er ist nicht dafür gedacht um unterwegs Flüssigkeiten zu transportieren
fields.name: The Tee Shaker

fields.short_description_en: Oolong tea is a type of tea produced mainly in the Fujian Province and Taiwan. It's key feature is that it is semi-oxidised - it's gone through a carefully controlled process of heating and being exposed to the air, which releases the distinct oolong taste.

fields.short_description_de: China ist berühmt für seinen grünen und weiβen Tee. Wegen der nur leichten Okzidierung (Fermentierung) dieser beiden Teesorten bleiben nahezu alle Wirkstoffe des Teeblattes enthalten. Grüner und weiβer Tee gelten als Inbegriff für ein natürliches und authentisches Tee-Aroma - leicht, reinigend, und abhängig von der Sorte mit herben oder grasig-frischen Geschmacksnoten.

fields.description: 3 teas sampler pack - @20g of each tea

Iron Buddha (tie guan yin, an oolong tea) is the classic Chinese green tea, refreshing and light. We've selected a special variety which has a slightly crisp and tingling aftertaste that refreshes the taste buds and cleans the palette. It's especially good to serve before a meal with appetisers. This tea was picked in April 2011.

Jasmine Pearl (mo li hua long zhu) is a deliciously fragrant Chinese green tea scented with the leaves of a jasmine flower. Each pearl is hand-rolled, and unfurls slowly to release its flavour. Fantastic as a birthday gift, or for guests, the scent and taste of this tea is like nothing you've experienced before. This tea was picked in April 2011.

Iron Buddha (tie guan yin, an oolong tea) is the classic Chinese green tea, refreshing and light. We've selected a special variety which has a slightly crisp and tingling aftertaste that refreshes the taste buds and cleans the palette. It's especially good to serve before a meal with appetisers. This tea was picked in April 2011.
Includes pot, lid and removable glass infuser.

fields.text: Ordering was quick and easy, and I got the tea delivered within a few days. It comes in an airtight packet which helps with preserving the freshness of the tea, even once it's opened. I really enjoy the tea, I add a tiny bit of sugar in it, and that makes it perfect for me. It's delicious hot and cold as well and has a lovely flavour, with a hint of jasmine, which definitely distinguishes it from usual green teas!
fields.short_text: Ordering was quick and easy, delivered in a few days. It's delicious hot and cold and has a lovely flavour, with a hint of jasmine, which definitely distinguishes it from usual green teas!

fields.text: This tea is a green Tie Guan Yin oolong that has been charcoal roasted. It was incredibly aromatic and I just had to use my aroma cups so that I could really take it in. The taste was woodsy and mildly smokey with a floral sweetness in the finish. This tea was really interesting because despite the roasting, it had many of the qualities of a green oolong. I did three consecutive steepings but the leaves definitely had a lot more to give. I've been very impressed with all of the teas that I've tried from Min River Tea Farm. Their teas are very affordable, especially for the quality of the leaf. I would definitely recommend this tea.
fields.short_text: It was incredibly aromatic ... woodsy and mildly smokey with a floral sweetness in the finish. I would definitely recommend this tea.

fields.text:
During my weekly White Crane Kung Fu classes, for a number of years now, I've heard told what have often seemed (at least to me) incredible stories about ever-more delicate tasting Chinese teas. I heard the tales of utterly sublime teas with, I must admit, a degree of scepticism. For, having enjoyed several varieties of Chinese tea (purchased in my local Chinese supermarket) for a good many years, I was familiar with their obvious superiority to the 'local brew' i.e. PG Tips. But the way some of these Chinese teas were described in class...

Well, Chris West, proprietor of the Min River Tea Farm, I salute you. My eyes are well and truly opened. I see what all the fuss is about, I do. The Iron Buddha tea you've sent me is something quite different from Chinese teas I've drunk in the past. A whole lot more fragrant and full of flavour. I'm looking forward, in a way I could never have previously imagined, to tasting the other two teas you sell, in due course.

And that is perhaps, at least for me, the really best bit of your website. You don't sell hundreds of teas. I'm sure you've tasted hundreds of teas, but you don't sell them. You choose the best ones out of the hundreds of different variations that you've come across – and you sell those ones to me. And for selling me the best, I thank you!

fields.text: I know many tea drinkers who do not enjoy Lapsang Souchong. While I agree that it can be an acquired taste, I think that a lot of this stems from the fact that many Lapsangs are overly smoked to mask a lower quality leaf. This tea was smokey, but in a much more mild way than most examples that I have tried. It was woodsy with notes of hazelnut and a lingering sweet aftertaste. There was none of the burnt rubber tire taste that is most often associated with this type of tea. I've been really impressed with the teas that I've tried from Min River Tea Farm and this one was no exception. I would definitely recommend this tea.

fields.content:
Do you know where in the supply chain your cup of tea is most carbon polluting? It's got to be the shipping or packaging, right?

Wrong! It's actually in the home where the most "pollution-per-cuppa" occurs.

Actually, you don't need to feel that guilty - loose-tea is still way better than beer, coffee or soft drinks when it comes to carbon output. But if you want to find out what you can do to improve the carbon-footprint of your cup of tea, here's where to start:

fields.meta_description: Photo and video guides to brewing Chinese tea, including oolong Iron Buddha (tie guan yin), da hong pao and Jasmine Pearls tea.
fields.title: Brew Your Chinese Tea
fields.content:
The perfect cup starts with hot water, a pinch of fresh tea leaves and a few minutes of your time.

Looking for detailed brewing guides for your tea?

1. Boiling water

Chinese tea should be brewed with boiling water. Different teas have different perfect temperatures, and a simple rule of thumb is that green tea like our Iron Buddha tea needs 80 degree water, but red teas like our Big Red (da hong pao) need a higher 90 degree temperature.

2. Wash the tea

Even fresh tea is inherently 'dirty', as it carries a lot of tea dust with it. So, for a better taste, using a tea strainer, pour boiling water over the tea leaves to wash them, and discard the water. Now you can start brewing the tea.

3. Brewing time

Once you've washed the tea, cover it in boiling water and leave to steep for about 1-2 minutes. Green teas need around 1 minute, and red teas slightly longer. Remember that Chinese teas become bitter if you stew them for too long, so for best results, use a tea strainer and remove the tea leaves from the water when the tea is ready.

fields.meta_description: Get to grips with the basics of Chinese tea, including where it comes from, how to brew it, and how it is made.
fields.title: Tea basics
fields.content:
Drinking loose-leaf Chinese tea is not complicated, and there's no big ceremony. Here's our super-short introduction to Chinese tea.

Chinese tea is loose-leaf tea

The Chinese tea that we sell is loose-leaf - no tea bags! It's also full-leaf, which means the whole tea leaf is picked and processed, and you get the full flavour of the tea leaf in your cup.

All tea comes from the same plant

All tea comes from the same type of plant, camellia sinesis. The differences between flavours or varieties of tea depends on where the tea is grown and how it is processed. We'll talk a lot about the location of a tea, or the processing method, because this determines the taste and quality.

Tea bags are the ugly cousin of our tea

Whereas our tea is full leaf, the teabags most people are used to drinking are often called "tea dust" in Chinese tea circles. That's because they often are - tea bags are made using the lowest quality tea leaves, stems and leftovers, and then undergo a process called 'Crush-Tear-Curl' which grinds the tea into an unrecognisable powder.

There's no special ceremony or equipment

Brewing a pot of Chinese tea is quite similar to brewing a cup of coffee at home - you just need a pot and hot water. There's no ceremony you need to perform. If you're really in a rush, you can just put tea leaves in a cup and add hot water!

You can brew the same tea leaves many times

Unlike a teabag, which loses it's flavour after 1 brew, tea leaves can be re-brewed 3-5 times without losing flavour. In fact, most of the time the 2nd brew is the best. So you don't need to throw away the tea leaves after they've been brewed - just add more hot water to the pot.

Try different varieties to suit you

There are hundreds of different varieties of Chinese tea. There's no 'perfect' tea, and you should find something that suits you. Also, the Chinese believe that red teas are better in winter, and green teas should be drunk in summer. So don't worry about trying different types to find your preferred taste.

Want to start your tea drinking journey?

We've got high quality teas for sale at great prices - check it out now.

fields.meta_description: Popular questions and answers about Chinese tea drinking, buying, preparation and varieties.
fields.title: Tea FAQs
fields.content:
These are some of the most frequently asked questions about Chinese tea. If this doesn't help, why not contact us and ask your question.

  • Do I need a special teapot or equipment?
  • How do I brew Chinese tea?
  • How much tea should I put in each cup?
  • How should I store my teas?

Do I need a special teapot or equipment?

In short, no. You don't need special equipment to brew loose-leaf Chinese teas - just boiling water and a cup. There are lots of specialist utensils, but they're not essential.

How do I brew Chinese tea?

It's really simple - if you're feeling extra lazy, just put the tea leaves in a mug, add boiling water, and you're good to go. Otherwise, you can use an ordinary teapot, add the leaves and leave them to steep before pouring.

How much tea should I put in each cup?

You'll roughly need 2-3 big pinches per cup (assuming you're using normal sized 'mugs'). For a pot, use the same measure per person.

How should I store my teas?

Teas will keep for a long time usually. Green teas like Iron Buddha should be sealed and refridgerated, and will last about 1 year like this. The Big Red or Jasmine Pearls can be stored at room temperature and will last around 1-2 years.

fields.meta_description: Chinese tea has hundreds of different varieties, depending on the type of plant, location and processing method. Take a look at our introduction to Chinese oolong, yan cha, scented teas, green teas and red teas.
fields.title: Types of Chinese tea
fields.content:
There are hundreds of varieties of Chinese tea, but it's easy to understand the main groups.

White teas

White teas are rare, and have a beautiful light coloured leaf.

Oolong tea

Oolong teas are semi-oxidised, and can be green or red teas.

Red teas

Red teas are fully-oxidised teas often with a beautiful rich brew.

Green teas

Fresh and lightly processed green teas are the real epitome of Chinese teas.

How to choose your tea

If you're not sure how to choose the right tea for you, the best advice is... don't worry! We work hard to select teas that can be appreciated by anyone, whether you're a hardened coffee drinker looking for a healthier alternative, or just a casual tea drinker looking for something new.

Red teas like The Big Red tend to have a stronger flavour, and are great enjoyed at work or in the mornings. The caffeine content isn't high, and you can enjoy a stronger taste of tea as you go about your day.

Green teas like our Iron Buddha or Jasmine Pearls often have a cleaner and purer taste. They're best enjoyed in moments of calm, before or after a meal, or when you're just sitting back and taking it easy.

None of our teas are difficult to brew - if you're not sure about how to brew tea, just check out our simple guides to brewing tea here.

fields.meta_description: How much loose-leaf tea do you need to put in each cup or pot? Here's our no-nonsense guide to tea weights and sizes.
fields.title: Weights and sizes
fields.content:
Knowing how much tea to put in the pot can get confusing - here's a quick-start guide.

4 grams per-person - one big pinch

The simplest and easiest measure is 4 grams of tea per-person - that's about 1 big pinch of your tea for each person. This works well if you're brewing tea the traditional European/American way (ie. in a big teapot or using a tea-infuser in the mug).

The traditional Chinese way

If you're brewing up your tea the traditional Chinese way using a gai wan then we recommend you put a bit more tea in - around 7 grams, or two big pinches. The traditional tea ceremony uses more tea, but you brew it for less time (for a stronger but cleaner flavour).

A bag of our tea

Our teas are sold in 100g bags. To help customers understand the weights and measures, we often say that each bag is equal to 50 cups of tea. We work this out by assuming that you'll rebrew the tea leaves at least 2 times (like you're supposed to!), and you'll put around 4 grams in each cup.

Practice makes perfect

The above measures are good for every day use, but of course, every tea is different. If you're looking for 'the perfect' cup of tea, then we advise you to use trial and error with your weights. Try a little bit more or less, and see how it affects the taste.

fields.title: What is Oolong Tea?
fields.content:
乌龙茶

wū
lóng
chá

Oolong tea is a type of tea produced mainly in the Fujian Province and Taiwan. It's key feature is that it is semi-oxidised - it's gone through a carefully controlled process of heating and being exposed to the air, which releases the distinct oolong taste. There are many types of Oolong tea, ranging from green to red, but all undergo a similar process of wilting, oxidisation, roasting and then fixing.

What makes an Oolong tea?

Oxidisation is the key process in making an oolong tea. Depending on whether the tea master is preparing a red or green oolong, the amount of oxidisation will vary between 20-80%.

In simple terms, oxidisation means the changes that happen when tea is exposed to air. When tea leaves are exposed to air (after being picked) they begin to break down, in a similar way to how an apple or banana goes brown if you leave it outside.

In the manufacture of an oolong tea (see a great step-by-step explanation here), the tea leaves are carefully exposed to heat and air in a number of different ways, for anywhere between 2 to 18 hours. The oxidisation starts with drying under the sun, continues with the leaves being bruised and heated in a large tumbler, and then finishes with a specialised process called sha qing which stops any further oxidisation.

For a green oolong tea such as Iron Buddha the oxidisation process will be short, perhaps a few hours. For a darker red oolong like The Big Red the oxidisation process may take up to 18 hours.

After the oxidisation is stopped, the tea leaves will be shaped and then dried.

Types of Oolong tea

The most commonly known types of oolong tea are tie guan yin, a green oolong tea from Anxi County in Fujian and perhaps da hong pao, a Wuyi red tea. There are also many oolongs also grown and produced in Taiwan (for example, the famous a li shan oolongs and dong ding oolong), and some in GuangDong province also - there's a comprehensive list on Wikipedia. You can even find oolong variations being grown in New Zealand and America now also.

Do you want to try an Oolong tea?

We sell two types of Oolong tea - a stunning red oolong from Wuyi mountain and also a light and crisp green tie guan yin from Anxi in Fujian.

The oolong taste

Oolong teas are hugely popular with tea lovers, especially in Fujian Province. Green oolong teas all tend to share a similar rich buttery taste, mixed with a natural vegetal edge. The bitter taste of chlorophyll can become overpowering if brewed too long, but generally if properly brewed the taste is light and clean.

Red oolongs tend to be woodier and more tannic, with strong roasted flavours. Many oolongs are mixed with fruit or honey to augment the natural fruitiness, although traditional manufacturing in China often disdains adding flavours to teas post-processing.

The most popular and famous oolong teas tend to be green in colour (although they're not classed as 'green teas'), which often share a rich, buttery taste.
fields.content_de:
乌龙茶

wū
lóng
chá

Oolong Tee wird hauptsächlich in Chinas Fujian Provinz und Taiwan angebaut. Das Hauptmerkmal der Herstellung ist dass Oolong Tee halb fermentiert ist, durchläuft einen kontrollierten Prozess bei dem Hitze zugeführt wird und der Tee der Luft ausgesetzt wird, wobei die Blätter mit dem Sauerstoff reagieren und der typische blumig-runde Oolong Geschmack freigesetzt wird. Alle Oolong Teesorten einen ähnlichen ähnlichen Herstellungsprozess bei dem die Blätter gewelkt, okzidiert und geröstet werden, doch abhängig von der Oxidationsdauer nähern sich die einzelnen Sorten eher an einen grünen oder schwarzen Tee.

Was macht einen Oolong Tee aus?

Oxidation ist der zentrale Schritt bei der Herstellung eines Oolong . Abhängig davon, ob der Teemeister einen grünen oder schwarzen Oolong zubereitet, beträgt der Oxidationsgrad zwischen 20 und 80 Prozent.

Einfach ausgedrückt ist Oxidation er Prozess bei dem dieTeeblätter nach dem Pflücken der Luft ausgesetzt werden und die Inhaltsstoffe der Teepflanze mit Sauerstoff reagieren, wie etwa bei einer Banane oder einem Apfel die braun werden wenn man sie drauβen liegen lässt.

Bei der Herstellung eines Oolong-Tees (see a hier Schritt für Schritt erklärt), werden die Teeblätter auf verschiedene Art und Weise während 2 und 18 Stunden Luft und Hitze ausgesetzt. Der Oxidationsprozess beginnt mit dem Trocknen in der Sonne, danach werden die Blätter gequetscht und in einem groβen Behälter erhitzt und zum Schluss wird in dem sha qinggenannten Prozess jede weitere Oxidation gestoppt.

Für einen grünen Oolong wie den Iron Buddha beträgt der Oxidationsprozess nur wenige Stunden, für einen dunkleren Oolong wie den The Big Red hingegen, kann die Oxidation bis zu 18 Stunen dauern.

Nachdem die Oxidation beendet ist, werden die Teeblätter geformt und getrocknet.

Oolong Teesorten

Die bekanntesten Oolong Teesorten sind Tie Guan Yin, ein grüner Oolong aus dem Anxi Bezirk in der Fujian Provinz und vielleichtDa Hong Pao, ein schwarzer Tee aus dem Wuyi Gebirge. Darüber hinaus gibt es einige sehr guten Oolong Tee, die in Taiwan angebaut und hergestellt werden (zum Beispiel die berühmten A Li Shan Oolong Sorten und Dong Ding Oolong), sowie einige aus Chinas Guangdong Provinz - auf Wikipedia gibt es eine recht vollständige Liste. Mittlerweile gibt es sogar Oolong Tee der in Neuseeland und Nord Amerika angebaut wird.

Möchten Sie einen Oolong Tee probieren

Wir verkaufen 2 Sorten Oolong Tee - den umwerfenden schwarzen Oolong aus dem Wuyi Gebirge und den leichten, frischen grünen Tie Guan Yin aus Anxi in Fujian.

Der Oolong Geschmack

Unter Teeliebhabern wird Oolong besonders geschätzt, vor allem in der Fujian Provinz. Grüner Oolong hat oft einen buttrig-weichen, leicht süβen Geschmack. Wenn der Tee zu lange aufgebrüht wird, überlagert der bittere Geschmack des Chlorophylls unter Umständen das leichte und reine Aroma, das diesen Tee ausmacht, daher sollte darauf besonders Acht gegeben werden.

Schwarzer Oolong tendiert zu einem waldigeren Geschmack und weist ein stärker . Many oolongs are mixed with fruit or honey to augment the natural fruitiness, although traditional manufacturing in China often disdains adding flavours to teas post-processing.

The most popular and famous oolong teas tend to be green in colour (although they're not classed as 'green teas'), which often share a rich, buttery taste.
