fields.meta_description: Our teas come from the Fujian Province, one of the oldest tea growing and trading centres in China. Find out more about Fujian teas.
fields.title: About the Fujian Province
fields.content:
Our teas all originate from the eastern provinces of China, in three of China's most renowned tea-growing areas.

A map of southern China's Fujian province, where all our tea is grown and processed.

About the Fujian Province

The Fujian Province, on the coast of southern China, is one of the world's most famous tea growing areas. For hundreds of years, tea has found a home here in the mountainous interior regions, which enjoy a perfect balance of sunshine and warmth in summer, and rain in the autumn and mild winters.

Fuzhou, the tea capital of the world

Fuzhou, the capital of the province, is one of the world's historical trading ports. Early western traders established themselves quickly in Fuzhou, at the mouth of the Min River, picking up the tea shipments delivered down the river from often inaccessible inland tea farming areas.

Later, Fuzhou became a treaty port with significant western settlements in the southern part of town. Tea was a key commodity for the average British citizen at the time - not much different from today then!

Fujian tea today

Today, the region is renowned across China and the world for its tea growing and culture. Two of China's recognised '4 famous teas' come from this region - Iron Buddha (tie guan yin) and The Big Red (da hong pao). In Fuzhou itself, Jasmine tea (mo li hua) is produced in abundance and the locals say that the "smell can be heard" on the streets.

Whilst modern transportation means the inland mountain areas are slightly more accessible, tea growing has not changed significantly - the best tea farms are often found on high, remote mountainsides, and the methods of producing tea are true to traditional practices, relying on manual labour and the skill of the farmer.

fields.meta_description: The skill of brewing Chinese lies in the brewing time - learn how to bring out the natural flavours and avoid bitterness in your brew.
fields.title: Brewing times
fields.content:
While every tea is different, there's still a few basic guidelines that apply when you're brewing any tea.

In a teapot or mug - 1-2 minutes

For regular daily brewing of your teas in a teapot or mug, roughly 1-2 minutes (with 1 Pinch per-person) will be perfect for most teas. Less than one minute will probably result in a weaker brew, and longer than 2-3 minutes will give a bitter brew (see below about avoiding bitterness).

In a gai wan - 30 seconds

If you're brewing your tea the traditional Chinese way, then you'll normally want to use more tea, and brew it for less time. Typically, most teas brewed in a gai wan porcelain cup need only 30 seconds to release a good, strong flavour.

Avoiding bitterness

If you brew your tea for too long, the brew will often become bitter and tannic - this is a quality the Chinese call se which means 'dry and bitter'. In fact you don't need to brew your tea for that long. Especially with finer quality teas, sometimes 30-60 seconds is all you need to bring out the flavour, and 4-5 minutes will almost always result in bitterness.

Stronger taste

If you're looking for a stronger taste in your brew, don't brew the tea for longer! The trick of the trade is to add more tea leaves, but keep the brewing time the same - this will normally help bring out a stronger taste.

The 2nd and 3rd brews

You can infuse your teas multiple times, but as you rebrew, lengthen the time a little bit. Normally the 2nd brew won't be much longer than the first, but the 4th brew might need to be approximately double the time.

You should experiment with your favourite teas to find the perfect taste for you, but if in doubt, just check out our detailed brewing guides for each of our teas.

fields.title: How to brew The Big Red
fields.content:
The Big Red (da hong pao) is a heavily-oxidised red oolong tea - give it boiling water for 1-2 minutes and you'll be rewarded with a thick, syrupy brew.

The leaves will release a warm, rich and smokey body. The leaves appear brittle at first, but will slowly soften and unfurl, revealing whole leaves with a part-brown, part-green tinge. The aroma has a strong edge to it, while the liquid will be a thick and deep orange/red colour.

As always, use one big three-finger pinch per person, and brew it in a teapot, or directly in the cup (although you might want to use a tea strainer). Rebrew the leaves at least 3-4 times.

fields.title: It might take longer, but you'll get better tea.
fields.content:
From 22 May - 22nd June 2012, all orders will be delivered directly from our home in China. It will take approximately 10 days to deliver your order, compared to 2-3 days currently.

Why change?

We are running a short trial to see if we can reduce the prices you pay for tea, whilst actually increasing the quality you receive. For one month, we will be delivering all orders directly from China, and it will take around 10 days to receive your tea.

We're already proud to supply some of the best quality Chinese tea available in the UK, but we think it can still get better for you.

We normally offer 2-3 day delivery times, because we maintain a distribution centre in the UK that can ship orders to you faster than is possible direct from China. Unfortunately this also means that a significant proportion of your money goes into postage, shipping and distribution. Although it's important to many people to receive a delivery quickly, we're also hoping that many of our customers will be happy to wait a few days longer in return for better quality tea.

Feedback and questions

During this trial, we'd really appreciate your feedback. If you have strong opinions about the trial, or questions, just email chris@minrivertea.com and we'll be happy to hear from you.

Choose your Chinese tea now »

fields.title: How to brew Silver Needle
fields.meta_title: How to brew Silver Needle Tea
fields.content:
Silver Needle is a white tea, and so is extremely sensitive to temperature - use hot water, around 75 degrees, and brew for approximately 1 minute for the best results.

White teas like Silver Needle are very lightly processed, and so their flavour is very close to natural. The best flavour comes from treating the leaf gently, so leave the kettle to sit for around 3 minutes before pouring.

Unlike many roasted or oolong teas, the dry leaves and wet leaves are very similar - light green/yellow in colour and slightly curled. As they are brewed, they will soften and give off a vegetal, grassy aroma and very light green liquor.

As always, use a 3-finger pinch of tea per person, and brew in a teapot or directly in your mug. If you have a glass teapot, it's enjoyable to watch this tea infuse slowly. You can usually rebrew the leaves 3-4 times.
fields.content_de:
Silver Tee ist ein weiβer Tee und daher sehr temperaturempfindlich - benutzen Sie etwa 75° heiβes Wasser, Ziehzeit 3-5 Minuten.

Weiβe Teesorten wie Silver Needle werden nur leicht verarbeitet, ihr Aroma ist daher sehr natürlich. Für den besten Geschmack sollte daher behutsam mit den Blättern umgegangen werden und wir empfehlen dass Sie den Teekessel nachdem das Wasser kocht für etwa 3 Minuten stehen lassen bevor Sie den Tee aufgieβen.

Anders als bei gerösteten oder Oolong Teesorten, sehen die trockenen und nassen Teeblätter sehr ähnlich aus - der Farbton ist hellgrün/gelb und die Blätter leicht gekräuselt. Bei dem Aufbrühen werden die Blätter weicher und ergeben ein grasig-frisches Aroma und einen hellgrünen Aufguss.

Benutzen Sie eine Prise pro Person und brühen Sie den Tee in einer Teekanne oder direkt in der Tasse auf. Falls Sie eine Glaskanne haben, lohnt es sich einen Blick auf die allmählich ziehenden Teeblätter zu werfen. 3-4 Aufgüsse sind möglich
fields.meta_title_en: How to brew Silver Needle Tea
fields.content_en:
Silver Needle is a white tea, and so is extremely sensitive to temperature - use hot water, around 75 degrees, and brew for approximately 1 minute for the best results.

White teas like Silver Needle are very lightly processed, and so their flavour is very close to natural. The best flavour comes from treating the leaf gently, so leave the kettle to sit for around 3 minutes before pouring.

Unlike many roasted or oolong teas, the dry leaves and wet leaves are very similar - light green/yellow in colour and slightly curled. As they are brewed, they will soften and give off a vegetal, grassy aroma and very light green liquor.

As always, use a 3-finger pinch of tea per person, and brew in a teapot or directly in your mug. If you have a glass teapot, it's enjoyable to watch this tea infuse slowly. You can usually rebrew the leaves 3-4 times.

fields.title: How to brew Iron Buddha
fields.content:
Iron Buddha is a semi-oxidised green oolong tea - it loves hot (but not boiling) water and short steeps. 90 degrees and 1 minute steeping is all you need for this subtle green oolong.

As the leaves infuse, they'll unfold from their rolled shape, revealing large and full leaves. A good Iron Buddha will have a strong, deep green colour, which will fade the more times you brew it.

The Iron Buddha aroma is a unique buttery smell, rich and yet also slightly elusive. The liquor should have a thin, crystal green colour.

Use a big three finger pinch of tea leaves per person. Although you're free to brew this tea in a teapot or directly in your cup, if you have access to the traditional Chinese brewing equipment (gai wan etc.) then it will reward you.

An experts tip for this tea - many green teas are supposed to have a light taste, but if you like it strong, use slightly more tea leaves, and a much shorter brewing time. Don't brew for longer - you'll just get a more bitter and tannic taste.

fields.title: How to brew Jasmine Pearls
fields.content:
Jasmine Pearls need a gentle touch to release their sweet, fragrant flavour - use 80 degree water, a big pinch of the leaves, and steep for 1-2 minutes or until the leaves have fully unfurled.

All green teas are more sensitive to water temperature. Our Jasmine Pearls uses the young tea shoots, and so ease off on the water temperature - leave the kettle to sit for 2 minutes before you pour.

The aroma will be light, with a dominant jasmine floral air, but also some undertones of fruit and grass. The liquor should be somewhere between green and yellow, with a slight pink tinge.

Use a big 3-finger pinch of tea per person, and brew in a teapot. If you're serving this tea for guests, use a glass teapot if you can and watch the delicate pearls unfurl as they infuse.

The expert tip for Jasmine Tea is to keep the brewing time short - 1 minute is usually enough. If you brew it for longer, it will taste bitter, but a short brew will result in a soft, smooth and naturally sweet taste.

fields.meta_description: What's in a traditional Chinese tea set? Here's a quick guide to the essential equipment for brewing Chinese teas in the traditional way.
fields.title: Tea sets and brewing equipment
fields.content:
Although we're big fans of 'grandpa tea' drinking, it's also fun to brew Chinese tea the traditional way sometimes. This is the equipment you might need:

Tea cups and pots

The traditional Chinese method of serving tea is in tiny, thin porcelain cups - roughly a mouthful of tea in each. The cups are most often white in colour, which shows off the pure colour of your tea.

There are two main types of teapot - a gai wan and a small pot called yi xing. Most tea in southern China, from my experience, is drunk from the gai wan type. The pot is shaped like a small bowl, with a lid. The leaves are placed in, water added, and then the lid is used to strain out the leaves when you pour the tea.

Tea table

The Chinese tea table is ultimately a practical tool, although it has become a highly decorative and prized item in itself. You can spend anything from £20 to £2000 on a tea table, but don't worry too much about this!

The key feature of a tea table is that you can pour water onto it, and the water will drain off into a bucket or drain, and not the floor.

The Chinese way of brewing and serving tea typically involves lots of water and lots of spillage - some of it intentional! So having a table that you're not afraid of getting wet is important.

Tongs

A small tool, but very useful - a small set of bamboo or metal tongs helps to grasp hot teacups, remove tea leaves from pots or cups, and otherwise manage your tea set.

Tea strainer

Although not essential, a tea strainer is often used to avoid getting tea leaves into the teacups. When you're drinking tea from a tiny Chinese tea cup, getting a tea leaf in the cup can be a big annoyance (although it's not really a problem if you're drinking from a large traditional English mug.

Separate pouring pot

The final piece of semi-essential tea equipment is a separate pouring pot - once you've brewed the tea in your gai wan, to avoid getting any leaves in the cups, you can strain your tea into a glass serving pot to serve. This just enhances the tea drinking, but is not 100% essential.

fields.meta_description: Water quality and temperature make a big difference in the taste of your Chinese teas - check out our guide to the right water for brewing Chinese tea.
fields.title: Water temperature and quality
fields.content:
Just like a fine whiskey, brewing a great cup of Chinese tea requires good ingredients and clean, clear water.

Water temperature

The right temperature of water varies depending on the type of tea - roughly speaking, dark teas (red or black) should be brewed with boiling water, and green teas should be brewed with slightly off-the-boil water (around 80 degrees).

Green teas are fresher and more sensitive to temperature, so using boiling water will actually damage the leaves slightly, altering the flavour and giving you a sub-optimal taste.

Water quality

The quality of water coming from your taps or kettle plays a huge part in the taste of your tea. Obviously, if you're after the perfect cup of tea, you might use bottled mineral water to ensure the taste - probably only for the tea-obsessed!

Otherwise, if you're from a extremely hard-water area, you might want to use a water filter before you brew your tea, and also regularly clean your kettle and keep it free of limescale. In London and most of the UK, the water is relatively hard, meaning that you will really notice the difference between a tap-water cup of tea, and a filtered-water cup.

fields.meta_description: An introduction to the traditional Chinese tea ceremony, including equipment, steps to take and how to serve tea to your guests.
fields.title: The tea ceremony
fields.content:
The Chinese tea ceremony is time-honoured and follows distinct steps - here's a quick introduction to the tea ceremony.

The Chinese tea ceremony is beautiful to watch, and is a great way to drink tea. Compared to the Japanese tea ceremony, it is less ritualistic and focuses more on the tea and social aspects than the ritual itself. There's three main steps - preparing the equipment, washing the tea, and serving.

Equipment needed for a Chinese tea ceremony

You don't need a lot of special equipment for the Chinese tea ceremony - normally just a small traditional pot for brewing tea, a tea table, and small Chinese tea cups - take a look at the picture below of my own tea set.

There are lots of other utensils and equipment you can buy, but these are the absolute basics - the only other thing I might recommend is a set of small tongs, to avoid burning your fingers!

Preparing the cups

A key aspect of the ceremony is to wash and warm the utensils. With your boiling water, pour hot water over all the cups, pots and utensils that you will use. You can normally pour a small amount of water over the biggest pot, and then tip that water over the other cups.

Washing the equipment has obvious benefits, but warming is important too - temperature of the water used to brew the tea is important, so if your cups are icy cold, it won't help your tea infuse at the right heat.

Washing the tea

Tea is inherently 'dirty' - it's a natural product and doesn't go through any cleaning process before it is used, so the tea ceremony involves washing the tea.

Put a few pinches of your tea in the pot, and pour in hot water - cover the tea completely, and let it infuse for around 20 seconds. Using the lid of the teapot, you can move the tea leaves around, ensuring they're all evenly cleaned. Once it's done, empty out the water, but keep the tea leaves.

Brewing the tea

Once your tea is washed, you can start to brew it for real. Pour hot water in again, filling the tea pot and cover with the lid. Let it sit for around 1-2 minutes depending on the tea.

Pouring the tea is the real art of the ceremony - you can either pour directly from the teapot into the cups, but you need to make sure that no leaves spill into the cup. You can use the lid of the pot as a strainer, but this might take some practice.

Most tea sets will also come with a separate glass pot and tea strainer. You pour the tea from the teapot into the separate glass pot, through the strainer, and this way, no tea leaves can get into the final brew.

Serving

Tea is social, and serving expresses an important part of Chinese culture. If you're the host, your job is to serve everyone else before yourself, and make sure that their cups are always full. So, going around the table, pour out cups for everyone else present - this expresses the Chinese custom of 客气 (ke qi). It literally means, "the air of a guest", but we'd most likely translate it as 'hospitality'.

fields.meta_description: Chinese tea is made according to traditional and ancient methods - read our short guide and photo gallery about how Chinese tea is made.
fields.title: How is Chinese tea made?
fields.content:
Chinese tea follows ancient and time-honoured methods for processing tea leaves and making tea.

1. Picking - the tea is picked when new shoots push through - click to see more »

2. Drying - the tea is laid out under the strong sun to dry the surface water away

3. Wilting - for up to 18 hours, the tea is wilted at low heat to release the flavours

4. Baking - depending on the type of tea, the leaves are now baked until they change colour.

5. Rolling - either by hand or machine, the leaves are rolled into thin or round shapes

6. Selection - workers now manually sort the leaves, removing stems, roots or other waste.


Although there are hundreds of different varieties of Chinese tea, they all follow a roughly similar process. The guide below explains the main steps used to process a tea from picking to brewing.

1. Picking

Chinese tea is normally picked twice a year, in spring and autumn. The exact time depends on the skill of the tea farmer, who will look at the tea bushes and evaluate if they are ready. Normally, they'll look for a branch with two full grown leaves, and one newly sprouted leaf.

2. Drying

The tea is first dried in the sun - this only lasts about 20-30 minutes, and removes the surface water from the leaves. The leaves are spread out on the ground, and turned once or twice before they're ready for the next stage.

3. Warming and wilting

The tea leaves are now placed in a type of dryer, normally with heat provided via a wood burning stove. The leaves are gently heated for up to 18 hours, and turned regularly. This starts the process of oxidisation, releasing the flavours of the tea. At this stage, the fragrance of the tea leaves is overpowering and absolutely fantastic!

4. Baking

The tea leaves are now normally baked. Depending on the type of tea, the length of baking will vary. Dark teas like The Big Red (da hong pao) are baked until the leaves are 70% brown, whereas green teas like Iron Buddha (tie guan yin) are baked for much shorter periods.

5. Rolling

After baking, the teas are normally rolled, either by hand or by machine. This does two things - it releases the natural flavours inside the tea, and also shapes the leaves.

6. Selection

At this point, the tea leaves are ready to be hand-selected. At this point, the tea grower will pull out the stems, roots, or broken leaves from the tea, so that the end product consists of just fine quality tea leaves.

fields.meta_description: All tea is made from the Cameilia Sinises plant - Chinese tea is any tea grown and processed in the traditional Chinese way. Find out more here.
fields.title: What is Chinese tea?
fields.content:
中国茶

zhōng​
guó
chá

Chinese tea encompasses hundreds of different flavours and styles of tea, all grown and produced in China. A distinct culture of brewing and drinking Chinese tea, called gong fu cha has existed for thousands of years, and is still practiced widely today as a simple gesture of welcome for friends, or as an honoured ceremony for guests and business associates.

All types of Chinese tea (in fact, all types of tea in the world) come from the same species of plant - camellia sinesis. What defines a Chinese tea is simply where it is grown, and the methods used to process it.

There are actually hundreds of varieties of Chinese tea, but they are often classified into five main varieties - green, red, oolong, puer and white. The differences between them are given by the tea farm location, type of soil, growing conditions, and minute differences in the processing methods used.

Chinese teas are generally thought of as any tea from mainland China or Taiwan, although some teas are also being grown in the USA and other countries using traditional Chinese methods.. The tea production methods are centuries old, and until relatively recently were carefully guarded secrets. Chinese tea production follows a time-honoured routine of plucking, drying, baking and forming the tea leaves.

fields.title: Where is Iron Buddha tea grown?
fields.content:
Our Iron Buddha (tie guan yin) comes from Anxi County in the Fujian Province.

Anxi County is one of the most famous tea growing regions in China. Many of China's classic green and oolong teas come from this mountainous region. It enjoys the perfect climate for tea growing - warm in summer, cool in winter, and with ample rain in spring and autumn.

Looking to buy some Iron Buddha tea? Click for info »

fields.meta_description: Learn more about Fuzhou, the capital of the Fujian Province and the home of Jasmine Pearls tea.
fields.title: Where are Jasmine Pearls grown?
fields.content:
Our Jasmine Pearls Chinese tea is made in Fuzhou, China.

Jasmine Pearls tea originally comes from Fuzhou, the capital of the Fujian Province. In the past, and still today, Fuzhou is a renowned tea trading centre. Although you can buy any type of tea imaginable here, a short walk around town and you can't miss the delicate fragrance of jasmine wafting from tea shops. In fact, there's a famous saying here - "In Fuzhou, you can hear the smell of Jasmine".

Want to try out our Jasmine Pearls tea? Click to view details »

fields.meta_description: Find out more about Wuyi Mountain, the birthplace of da hong pao oolong tea.
fields.title: Where is the Big Red grown?
fields.content:
The Big Red tea (da hong pao) comes from Wuyi Mountain in the Fujian Province.

Wuyi Mountain is one of China's most renowned tea growing areas. It's situated in the centre of the Fujian Province, and traditionally, teas were shipped from here direct to Fuzhou along the Min River, which runs past the base of the mountain. Today, much of the Wuyi Mountain area is a nationally protected heritage park, and a tourist attraction as well known for it's stunning peaks and bamboo rafting as it is for tea!

Want to buy some Da Hong Pao tea? Click for more info »

fields.title: Postage and Packaging
fields.content:
We hope that buying our teas is as simple as possible. So, we charge a single fee for postage, regardless of how many items you order.

Shipping rates

We charge a standard £3 fee for postage on every order. If you order more than £50 of tea, we'll ship it for free. We hope that you find this fair and simple.

Shipping information

All orders are shipped to you from our warehouse in the UK using Royal Mail standard post. Your tea is shipped the day you order it, and should arrive between 1-2 days later. Occasionally, orders might be delayed (for example, during bank holidays, festivals, or under extreme circumstances). If your order doesn't arrive within 4-5 days or not at all, please contact us immediately and we will help resolve the problem.

Tea packaging

Our tea is directly packaged in plastic freeze-dry bags to ensure it stays fresh, and then shipped in sturdy recyclable cardboard boxes which prevent crushing. You can read more about our packaging and environmental policy here.

fields.title: Privacy - your data
fields.content:
When you purchase tea from our site, you will need to give us some data about you and where you live. We take data privacy very seriously, and will never pass on your information to third parties.

What data do you give us?

If you order tea from us, you will need to provide your name, email address, and physical address. We will never sell or rent this information to any third party. Your name and address will be provided to our fulfillment agency in the UK who comply with our data protection and privacy policies. We hate spam as much as you do.

We also collect some data from you through online forms (eg. Tell a friend). Unless you explicitly consent, we will never use the email addresses you give us to send you spam or marketing materials, and we will not share that information with anyone else.

As you browse the site, we collect certain anonymous information from your computer and browser, like your IP address. We may also use 'cookies' to store information in your browser to help improve your browsing experience on this site. This information can never and will never be used to identify you.

What do we do with your data?

The Min River Tea Farm is bound by UK and EU data privacy laws. Unless you consent to receive emails from us, we will never use your email address to send promotional information.

The data you give us is stored on secure servers protected by industry standard protocols. We never distribute that data, and use it only for the purposes of fulfilling your orders. Your name and address is used by our fulfillment agent to process and send your tea, who comply with our data protection policies.

What to do if you have a complaint?

If you have a question, complaint or problem regarding data privacy, please contact us immediately by email at mail@minrivertea.com

You may not download, reuse, resell or otherwise copy any element of the site content (text, images, code) without express written permission from the owners of the Min River Tea Farm.

You are welcome to link to this site, provided that your link is not framed in a derogatory, misleading or offensive manner. You may not use any Min River Tea Farm logo or graphical object without our express written consent.

You may not use this website for any fraudulent purposes, or in any way that intentionally disrupts or damages the site code or data. We reserve the right to edit or remove any information you post on this site (eg. reviews, photos) if it is deemed to be offensive, fradulent or otherwise in breach of these conditions.

Returns policy

We offer a "no questions" returns policy. If you're at all disappointed with any tea that you purchase from us, please contact us immediately.

Pricing and availability

We reserve the right to adjust prices stated on this site at any time without notice. Availability of products is not guaranteed - if you order a product that is subsequently found to be unavailable, we will contact you immediately to either cancel the order, or arrange a suitable alternative arrangement (eg. an alternative product, or delayed delivery).

Health and safety

We cannot be held responsible, and take no responsibility for any accidents, losses, damages or personal harm incurred during the use of our products. Preparation of tea, using boiling water, is performed at your own risk. Children should be supervised in the kitchen when handling boiling water.

Photo submissions

We donate £1 to Mind UK for every photo submitted to our site. Photos should feature you drinking tea. We reserve the right to reject any submissions that do not meet this criteria, and to edit or alter the picture for presentation purposes. By submitting a photo, you are agreeing that we can publish this photo on www.minrivertea.com. Submitting a photo does not constitute a legal contract or infer any obligation on us. You retain copyright over the original image.

fields.title: Where do we deliver?
fields.content:
We deliver worldwide - yes, that's everywhere in the world!

* we've safely delivered tea as far east as Australia, as far south as South Africa, as far north as Norway, and as far west as Oregon!

Deliveries are made from our base in the UK, but occasionally (for example, if a tea is out of stock) we will ship direct from China to your home. We'll always clearly indicate where your tea will be shipped from during the order process.

Delivery times

These are rough delivery times for each area of the world. Please note these are guidelines, and occasionally packages can take slightly longer (or slightly shorter) than indicated:

  • UK - 1-3 days
  • Europe and North America - 2-7 days
  • Rest of the world - 7-14 days

Postage cost

We charge a flat rate of £3 / €4 / $5 on each order, regardless of how much you order. If you order more than £50, your order is delivered for free. It's that simple.

Customs, taxes and inspections

Most countries do not levy tax on small commercial purchases, especially tea, and tea is usually inspected for safety when it leaves China, not when it arrives in your country. We clearly mark all parcels, and complete all required international customs declarations forms so your tea is delivered safely, legally, and with a minimum of delay.

Some countries (for example, the USA) require prior notice of commerical packages - we take care of this paperwork whenever we send tea to a customer, so you don't have to.

fields.meta_description: Old Iron Charcoal Oolong is a roasted oolong tea from Anxi County in Fujian - find out more here.
fields.title: Where is Old Iron Charcoal Oolong from?
fields.content:
Our Old Iron Charcoal Oolong is grown and processed in Anxi County, Fujian Province.

Anxi County is a mecca for oolong teas, and where two of our green oolongs are produced.

Old Iron Charcoal Oolong comes from Anxi County, a small mountainous area where many of China's most famous Oolong teas come from. Old Iron uses a regular green oolong tie guan yin tea as a base, and is then roasted over charcoal to give it a unique blend of pure green oolong and slightly fuller, woodier red oolong tastes.

fields.title: Suggestions
fields.content:
Choosing a Chinese tea to suit you isn't difficult - and remember, it'll be the healthiest, tastiest choice you make this year!

You don't need to worry about learning names and histories of thousands of teas - there's a few simple ways to choose:

If you're looking for a tea for yourself, then think about what kind of taste you like - if you're after a healthier coffee replacement, we strongly recommend The Big Red. It's got a slightly stronger taste, and a little bit of a caffeine kick if you need that in the mornings.

If you're trying to make healthy changes to your life, perhaps you'd prefer Iron Buddha. It's a green tea, and retains more anti-oxidants than other red teas. It can help you maintain a healthy digestive system, and the Chinese believe it has benefits for your throat, lungs and stomach.

For special occasions, gifts, or perhaps just those lazy Sundays reading a book, we'd recommend Jasmine Pearls - it's got a soothing and distinct jasmine scent, and is low in caffeine and healthy. For guests, it's the perfect pre-dinner drink to whet your appetite.

Hopefully that helps - if not, just contact us and we'd be happy to help out.

Want to buy high quality Chinese teas?

Check out our teas now, and choose the perfect brew for you »

fields.meta_description: We're the only Chinese tea company based in China full-time, and we sell a range of authentic teas sourced direct from farms near our home in southern China.
fields.title: About Min River Tea
fields.content:
Min River Tea is an online tea shop established in 2010 by Chris West and Bonnie Wang, a British/Chinese couple both hugely passionate about Chinese tea. In our first year our customers extended across Europe, the USA, and as far south as Australia and South Africa.

We sell a range of loose-leaf Chinese teas perfect for home, office or as gifts, tea taster packs to start you on your journey and hand-selected teaware.

Direct from the source

Our home is in Fuzhou, China, and we source all our teas direct from farms in Fujian, and neighbouring provinces. Because we don't use middlemen, annual buying trips or trading companies like our competitors, we can be selective about the quality we offer. It's why we think you can taste the difference (and also feel it in your wallet!)

Quality and standards

All of our Chinese teas are all hand-made using traditional methods, grown organically and processed without the use of chemicals, intensive farming methods or added flavourings or oils. We personally taste every batch to ensure the taste meets our standards.

Did you know we started in a tea shop in London?

Actually, it was one of our competitors tea shops....sshhhh!

fields.title: Press enquiries
fields.content:
For press and media enquiries, get in touch with us and we'll be happy to help.

Contact Chris West for any press enquiries about the Min River Tea Farm. We're also based in China, and can be available for comment or information regarding any aspect of the Chinese tea market.

fields.meta_description: The Min River Tea Farm was founded in 2011, and is one of the only Chinese tea retailers actually based in China. This is our story.
fields.title: Our story
fields.content:
We started selling tea in 2011, but the Min River Tea Farm had its origins a year earlier in an upmarket London tea house.

In 2010, I was sitting in a London tea house drinking a few grams of some pretty average Iron Buddha that I'd just paid £5 for. I'd been living in China for 4 years at this point, and I knew that good tea shouldn't cost this much.

At the time, there weren't many companies offering authentic Chinese teas, and what was on the market was massively overpriced. Today, although there is more selection, we're still one of only a tiny handful of companies selling Chinese tea who actually have roots in China - whether it's living here, speaking the language, or even just having visited!

Our name comes from the river running through Fuzhou, the Min Jiang. May years ago, tea growers would travel downstream from the mountainous inland regions of the Fujian Province to Fuzhou, where foreign and domestic traders waited eagerly. So, it felt natural to name ourselves after this historic river.

Do you want to know how to brew the perfect tea?

fields.meta_description: Our Chinese tea is sourced locally from organic tea suppliers and growers in the Fujian Province, China. We pride ourselves on superb quality, taste and service.
fields.title: About our teas
fields.content:
Our teas come from the Fujian Province in China - a world mecca for great loose-leaf teas

The Fujian Province in the south of China is one of the great tea growing regions of the world. Its mountainous terrain and warm climate are perfect for tea growing, and the long history and tradition of tea in this area has resulted in a spectacular variety and quality of teas.

In fact, the Fujian region was the birthplace of many modern Indian varieties of tea - early travellers and traders to the area such as Robert Fortune were tasked by the British government at the time to steal the Chinese tea cultivation secrets and assist in transplanting tea from China to India.

Our teas

We sell three classic Fujian teas, representing the pinnacle of tea growing in this region - the classic Chinese green tea Iron Buddha (tie guan yin), a rusty and warm red tea The Big Red (da hong pao) and a Fuzhou speciality, the hand-rolled Jasmine Pearls (mo li hua zhen zhu).

So that you can spend less time worrying about your tea, and more time enjoying it, we continually travel across the Fujian Province from our base in the capital, Fuzhou, searching for the best teas. Our standards are high, and we insist on only naturally grown, traditionally processed full-leaf teas.

  • Browse our teas and find your perfect brew »
  • Learn more about where our tea comes from »

fields.meta_description: Can't find the tea you're looking for? We're based in China, and offer a personal tea shopping service for those hard-to-find Chinese tea varieties.
fields.title: Personal tea shopping
fields.content:
If you're looking for something special that we don't normally stock - let us be your personal tea shopper!

We're based in China, so it's easy for us to find that special, rare or unique tea for you. We specialise in teas from the Fujian Province, and we'll get any tea that you like. We'll then package and deliver that tea to whereever you are.

If you want us to be your personal tea shopper, just get in touch and we can discuss your requirements. Typically, the price of the tea will vary depending on the local market cost, and our personal tea shopping must be a minimum of 2kg of tea (it can be different varieties). We also pass on any costs for shipping.

fields.meta_description: The Min River Tea Farm tea shop was founded by Chris West, a British expat living in Fuzhou, and his wife Bonnie, with a mission to bring simple, affordable and high quality teas to the UK.
fields.title: Our team
fields.content:
The Min River Tea Farm is run by a dedicated team of tea enthusiasts living and working in China.

Chris West (Founder)

I've been living here in China since 2007, and tea has just become a part of my life. It's a daily drink, a secret pleasure, an excuse to get together with friends, and an education sometimes too.

Favourite tea: Really into aged/roasted oolongs now like our Old Iron.


Bonnie Wang (Co-Founder)

I was born near Long Yan in Fujian Province, and tea has been a part of my life since I was a child. It's one of those things that really expresses our culture well - something enjoyed with guests or friends, a deep and long history, and above all, some simply amazing tastes!


Raphael Henkes (Sales/Promotion, Germany)

Raphael has recently joined minrivertea.com from his new home in Chengdu, south-west China. He's come on board to help share our great Chinese teas with our German-speaking cousins back home! Welcome Raphael!


Get in touch

If you'd like to get in touch about anything, even just a chat about tea or Chinese culture, please feel free to email us at chris@minrivertea.com

fields.meta_description: We wholesale Chinese teas to restaurants, cafes and other businesses in the UK - we're full time in China, and can source just about any tea you can think of at great prices.
fields.title: Wholesale/Trade
fields.content:
We wholesale our Chinese tea ready for your store, hotel, cafe or restaurant. Whatever your requirements, we're based full time in China and can source just about anything tea-related that you need.

Chinese tea for your customers

If you run a hotel, restaurant or cafe and you're looking to expand your range, Chinese tea is a great choice right now. More and more consumers are looking for healthier choices instead of coffee, and more adventurous beverages compared to the standard British cuppa.

Similarly, more and more Chinese tourists visiting the UK expect to find their usual creature comforts - a good quality green or red tea, and proper tea equipment to brew it with.

We can offer a custom range of cost-effective teas, packaged uniquely for you, as well as modern or traditional tea cups, pots and serving equipment.

Our products

We wholesale tea leaves and tea equipment for UK businesses, including:

  • A wide range of packaged tea leaves, available to resell to your customers in small portions (@7g servings, individually packaged)
  • Large orders (in quantities > 2kg) of tea for serving in tea-houses or restaurants
  • Traditional teapots and tea serving utensils
  • Tea tables

Quality guarantees

We're based in China and sell exclusively to the UK (the company is run by a British expatriate living in China). Every product you buy from us is sourced direct from farms or factories in China, with no middlemen involved. We check and handle every order with extreme care, and absolutely refuse to compromise on the quality of our tea or tea products.

We're also aware that Chinese tea can be a daunting subject - we're happy to discuss tea culture with you and your staff to ensure you can delight your customers with an authentic Chinese tea drinking experience, every time.

Get in touch with Chris at chris@minrivertea.com for more information.

fields.title: Oolong teas
fields.content:
One of the main varieties of Chinese tea is called oolong tea (wu long). The name has no real meaning, but it refers to a group of semi-oxidised teas, most often found in Fujian, Guangdong and Taiwan.

Semi-oxidised means that the leaves are part-roasted, and it gives the teas a unique, complex and full-bodied flavour. Typically, green oolong teas like our Iron Buddha are around 30% oxidised, whereas red oolongs like our The Big Red are around 70% oxidised.

Non-roasted green teas have a very thin, pure and clean taste - a green oolong typically has a rich, buttery aroma and a thicker taste. The attraction of this richer taste is clear: Iron Buddha (tie guan yin) is one of China's favourite teas and represents a 'gold standard' in tea quality.

Oolong tea also includes red teas, including the yan cha variety grown in Wuyi Mountain.

fields.meta_description: White teas are so-called because their leaves and liquor have a crystal clear and almost transparent colour - in fact it's still slightly green, but much less so than other green teas.
fields.title: What is white tea?
fields.content:
白茶

bái
chá

White teas are so-called because of their light, crystal clear liquor, and the layer of white 'fur' that is often found on the young leaf shoots used to make white tea. Popular in Fujian, white teas are often significantly more expensive than their green or black tea cousins.

Location

Chinese white teas are grown in many locations on the east coast of China. In Fujian Province, the areas north of Fuzhou such as Fu Ding (福鼎) and Ning De (宁德) are well known for their white teas - fu ding bai cha, Silver Needle (yin zhen) and bai mu dan. Further inland, Zheng He (政和) also produces a renowned white tea grown at a higher altitude than the northern Fujian varieties.

The leaves

The leaves of a white tea typically have a layer of 'fur' on them, which is quite natural - in Chinese this is known as the bai hao (白耗). White teas are often also defined by the use of only the tea-leaf sprouts (the young leaves) rather than fully grown leaves. Although you'll see many different types of leaves being used, the best is considered to be a 'wrap' of 2, 3 or even 4 leaves wrapped inside each other. This happens when the new tea shoot has been picked when it is just about to begin unfurling.

The taste

When brewed, White Teas are often extremely light tasting and vegetal. There should normally be three distinct tastes - an initial freshness which is called xiang wei (香味) in Chinese, followed by the baked taste that comes from the high-heat roasting, and then finally a third taste unique to that variety or farm - sometimes it's a sweetness, or other times a seaside tone (think salty sea air).

The processing

Whereas other teas often undergo a long and complex processing, white teas only have four simple stages - picking, oxidisation, roasting at high temperature and then sun-drying. After being picked, the oxidisation process can last for many hours, depending on the weather and conditions. After anywhere from 12-24 hours, a short burst of heat is applied to stop oxidisation. At this point the leaves are still soft, and so are then left to dry under the sun for a brief period, during which they become brittle.

The price

White teas are typically expensive, for two main reasons - firstly, the use of only tea-leaf shoots means a normal harvest does not yield as much tea as other types of tea. Secondly, while there is less processing, the teas must be packaged, sealed and stored very carefully in order to preserve the xiang wei so important to the taste.

fields.title: What is red tea?
fields.content:
红茶

hóng
chá

Red tea is sometimes referred to as black tea in the West - it refers to all types of tea where the liquor of the tea is red in colour. The dry leaves are often black or dark brown in colour, having undergone a long roasting process, and are fully-oxidised.

Red Chinese tea is so-called because once brewed, the liquor is a rich red colour. But in fact, many people refer to these as black teas, because the colour of the leaves is a dark brown/black.

Red teas are fully-oxidised - the whole leaf has been oxidised and turned brown. Typically, a red tea will have very small, shrunken leaves that are completely dark in colour. By comparison, red oolong teas still retain around 30% green in the leaves.

Our Lapsang Souchong is a great example of a full-oxidised Chinese red tea. Although it looks similar to other red oolong teas, it has a deeper, mustier taste accentuated by the unique pinewood roasting process.

fields.title: What is green tea?
fields.content:
绿茶

lǜ
chá

Green teas are lightly processed, lightly oxidised teas - while the category covers a wide range of tastes and processing methods, generally speaking green teas are dried but not roasted or oxidised and retain their original bright green colour, especially when brewed.

Green Chinese teas are non-fermented, non-oxidised, fresh tea leaves. They are wilted and dried in a similar way to other teas, but unlike other teas do not undergo any form of oxidisation or roasting. As a result, they have an exceptionally fresh and pure taste, and a beautiful light green colour.

Good Chinese green teas command high prices in China and across the world. Because they are fresh and unaltered by any excessive processing, a good green tea represents as close as it's possible to the original taste of tea. For example, genuine bi luo chun and long jing teas often sell for as much as £400 per half kilo in China, which tells you a lot about their taste and demand!

Green teas are light in caffeine and high in anti-oxidants, which is why many people believe them to be the most beneficial for health. They're most often grown in Zhejiang, Anhui and Jiangxi provinces, and often have quite a short shelf-life (3-6 months unrefridgerated).

fields.meta_description: Can and should you use milk and sugar in your tea? Help is at hand right here...
fields.title: Milk and sugar
fields.content:
A big question for many new drinkers of Chinese tea is - "can I add milk and sugar?!"

Milk

You can add milk to your Chinese tea, although it's not recommended. Typically, Chinese tea has a lighter flavour than 'builders tea' and so milk will almost totally overwhelm that taste. But if you really want to, add just a drop or two to a small cup (literally one or two drops of milk) and you'll still be able to appreciate the blend of tastes.

Sugar

Sugar can be added to Chinese teas, and in fact helps to make it more palatable and appealing to people with a sweet tooth as well as younger drinkers. If you're looking to wean yourself or your kids away from fizzy soft drinks, this is a great solution.

Normally, green teas don't take sugar as well as red teas, so if you enjoy a sweeter brew, then you might want to try our Jin Jun Mei (which has a naturally sweeter edge) with a drop of sugar.

We'd also encourage you to use rock sugar, or any unrefined sugar. Many of us drink Chinese tea for health reasons, so adding refined white sugar is counteractive to this.

The traditional way

If you're looking to drink Chinese tea the traditional way in China, then you should never add milk or sugar to any tea. In China, adding any flavours to your brew obscures the original taste of the tea, and if you're drinking an expensive and delicate leaf, then it is equivalent to mixing a Chateau Lafitte with lemonade!

fields.meta_description: Storing your teas properly can extend their live massively - find out more info.
fields.title: Storage
fields.content:
Storing your teas properly can extend their shelf life by up to 6 months, so take a few easy steps to help your tea stay fresher for longer.

Keep green teas cool!

Your green and white teas have undergone less processing than red or black teas - basically it means they are fresher and will degrade more quickly. So, white teas, green teas and green oolong teas must be kept in the fridge.

An unrefridgerated green tea might last around 3 months before its flavour starts to seriously degrade. But keeping it cooled in the fridge will extend that life to 9-12 months. It's not just good for your tea, but better for the environment too!

Red or black teas, because they have been fully dried and oxidised, do not need to be refridgerated. Just keep them relatively cool and dry, and they will remain fresh for up to 12 months.

Seal those bags!

Don't make the mistake we once made of keeping an expensive tea in the same fridge as smelly food! Most teas will absorb smells around them, especially green and white teas. So you should always try to air-seal your teas in air-tight containers like Tupperware boxes, ziplock bags or tins.

What to do with teas at the end of their lifespan?

If you have a tea that is reaching the end of it's lifespan, there's a few things you can do.

If you just want to use it up, then take a look at some other uses for tea. If you're feeling a bit more adventurous, an ancient trick of many tea masters for extending the lifespan of a tea (especially oolong or red teas) is to re-roast it. It's not the easiest thing to get right, so we suggest if you want to try this, get in touch with us first!

fields.title: Blended teas
fields.content:
Blended teas have become a big craze in the last few years - we don't sell them, but it's not hard to make your own.

As tea has taken off in popularity, more and more tea blends are popping up. This includes different tea varieties blended with each other, or fruit and herb blends. We don't sell any blended teas (we're a little bit purist like that), but there's nothing to stop you blending your own teas.

Where to start

The simplest blend is also the commonest - a little bit of sugar and a slice of lemon with your red tea! You can also play around with different herbs like mint to add a little twist to a brew. From there, you could play with adding dried fruits or fruit juices, mixing two varieties of tea together, or infusing the actual tea with a flavour (eg. storing a red tea with cinnamon sticks).

There's really no limit, and we'll try to post ideas here as and when we find them.

fields.meta_description: Tea isn't just for drinking - here's a few other ways you can use your tea after it's been brewed.
fields.title: Other uses for tea
fields.content:
Tea is an incredibly versatile plant, and whether you drink it, or put it in your food, there's a world of things you can do with the humble tea leaf.

Don't throw tea leaves away!

In Britain, the mark of a tight (cheap) person is someone that reuses their teabags. But when you're using high quality loose-leaf teas, you should reuse them! Most of the Chinese teas we sell can be rebrewed at least 3-4 times, and sometimes up to 6-7 times before they start losing their flavour.

Tea for compost

Tea leaves are great for composting - often people avoid composting tea because the tea-bags are not decomposible, but the raw tea leaves (like the ones we sell) are great for gardens! Just make sure you don't throw hot water on your plants!

Tea roots soak up bad smells

Now, it might be a little hard to get hold of, but tea roots are fantastic for soaking up smells like paint in a newly decorated house. If you can get hold of tea roots, just spread them around a room in small containers for a few days and let them do their work!

Take a bath in tea!

It sounds crazy, but you can actually bathe in Jasmine Tea! In Fuzhou, a popular weekend activity is bathing in the natural hot springs which surround the whole Min River area. Each hot springs will have many different pools, and quite often, a Jasmine Tea pool. I don't recommend using tea to replace soap, but at the least it will be the most fragrant bath you ever experienced!

fields.meta_description: Find out more about the impact of tea on the environment, and what you can do at home to improve the carbon footprint of your cuppa.
fields.title: Tea and the environment
fields.content:
We're hugely concerned with the impact of our tea on the environment. It's probably quite important to you too that your daily brew is high quality and not environmentally damaging, so we'll keep this page updated with links and information.

Carbon footprint of our Chinese tea

Evidence suggests that drinking loose-leaf Chinese tea is extremely low-carbon when compared to other drinks like traditional tea-bag tea, or soft drinks.

So when you buy a loose tea from us, it's undergone much less processing and comes in less packaging than a traditional tea bag tea.

Shipping impact

Our teas are shipped by air from China to the UK. It does have an impact on the carbon footprint of our tea, but unfortunately is an unavoidable step - for our teas to remain fresh and high quality, they must be shipped quickly from China to our warehouse in the UK.

What can you do?

In fact, in the life-cycle of a cup of tea (PDF), the largest carbon producer is you, in the home! There's a few things you can do to help improve the carbon profile of your tea:

  • Brew only enough water to fill your cup
  • Re-brew your tea leaves (good tea like ours will not lose its flavour)
  • Try to reuse your tea leaves after, in compost or in other ways
  • Recycle any packaging the tea comes in.
  • Store your tea correctly to reduce wastage

Interestingly, one huge factor in the carbon footprint of a tea is whether you take milk. Because of the high impact of milk production and transport, taking tea without milk will make a huge difference. Luckily, most Chinese teas are intended to be drunk without milk, so you're already starting out on the right foot.

fields.title: Our packaging
fields.content:
Our teas are packaged simply and efficiently - your money goes into better quality tea, not fancier boxes!

Preserving your tea

Your tea is delivered to you sealed in a thick and durable plastic bag. Compressed teas like Iron Buddha and Old Iron are freeze-dried, and more brittle teas such as The Big Red are not (freeze-drying would crush the delicate leaves).

Protecting it in transport

We ship your tea in a lightweight but strong cardboard box (which is of course recyclable) and cushion it is a layer of packing paper or foam. This prevents your tea being crushed or damaged, especially important for brittle black and red teas.

Our duty to the environment

We take our duty to the environment seriously, and we're sure you'll enjoy a guilt-free brew much more. Our packaging is designed to reduce waste, with no excess plastic, paper or cardboard used. It also means that you're also spending more on tea, rather than poor quality tea with expensive boxes!

fields.meta_description: A big question for many customers - are your teas organic? Find out all the information here.
fields.title: Are our teas organic?
fields.content:
A big question from many customers is always "are your teas organic?" Here's the not-so-short answer to that question.

Our teas are grown and processed by hand the traditional way, but most do not carry formal organic certification. We have strong reasons for this.

Firstly, organic certification is a long and costly process. Most small farms in China that we work with do not typically export their teas, and the domestic tea market in China does not insist on organic certification as a mark of quality (yet).

Secondly, most tea farms in China which do have organic certification charge significantly more for their teas. While the tea may not be better quality, you (the end consumer) end up paying more.

Finally, we're also concerned with some evidence that suggests that foods produced organically can often be less environmentally friendly than other types. Organic certification often results in less efficient use of land, and higher carbon and methane outputs than standard methods.

In most cases, our tea is produced on small, family owned farms where teas have been produced in a traditional way for many generations. Chemicals and machines are not used, and often workers are either extended family members, or part of a close community within the area - it means we never see the kind of worker exploitation often associated with teas produced in Africa for example.

The teas your drink are the same as the teas we enjoy every day, so rest assured that quality and taste are extremely important to us. Where possible, we also look at the carbon footprint of our teas and try to find a balance of price, quality and environmental credentials that means a guilt-free brew for you.

fields.title: Growing
fields.content:
Tea has been growing in China for many centuries, and even today most high quality teas are grown and produced in the same ancient locations using the same methods.

Tea (camelia sinesis) is typically grown in southern China, and most commonly in mountainous regions around and above 600m elevation. Although it will grow in many places, the Chinese believe that the finest quality teas come from farms on high mountains.

In fact, the tea plant is quite hardy, and given the right location and rainfall, does not need a huge amount of tending or cultivation. It enjoys hot, humid weather and strong sunshine in the summers, and mild winters, and doesn't like to be waterlogged (a mistake early botanists made when transplanting it from China to India). Farmers may often prune the plant in its early years to keep its height down (so it's easier to pick the top leaves) but otherwise.

Grow your own?

Depending on where you live, it's possible to grow your own tea plants. It's actually not a particularly pretty plant, and unless the leaves are processed it doesn't give off any strong smell - if you're planning to grow tea, plan to harvest it too!

You can find simple instructions for growing and preparing tea all over the web - if you need any tips or advice for processing, just get in touch!

fields.title: Harvesting
fields.content:
One of the biggest price differences between a quality tea and an average tea-bag tea is in the way it is harvested. Here's a little introduction to tea harvesting methods.

Machines or by-hand?

As a rule, good quality teas should be harvested by hand, and the difference is not just a feel-good-factor of hand-made teas.

Machine harvesting involves basically a huge vacuum-cleaner type contraption which sucks the leaves from the tea plant. There are small hand-held ones, or large-scale industrial ones. If you've ever seen or owned a mulch-making garden tool, then think about that in reverse and you'll get the idea.

When this happens, not just the soft leaves, but also twigs and stems are sucked up into the mix. The leaves themselves are broken, battered and bruised (which ruins the flavour) and there's more chance of a flavourless twig getting into your brew.

By comparison, hand-picked tea leaves (like ours!) arrive for processing in perfect condition, and are wilted and dried with all of their flavour and nutrients intact. It leads to a better tasting brew, but also better looking leaves with a fuller shape and colour. The trade-off is that hand-picking takes much longer, and is more labour-intensive, and so the price rises correspondingly.

fields.title: Stages of tea processing
fields.content:
How tea is processed defines its taste - all tea actually comes from the same plant, but only different methods of production decide if your tea is an oolong or a puerh.

Wilting

The first stage in making any tea is wilting. The leaves are laid out in the sun to air-dry for 30-40 minutes. This is often just to make sure the leaves are free of rain or dew, but it's also a critical first step in the oxidisation process.

Oxidisation

The oxidisation phase determines a large part of the taste of your tea. Oxidisation can take anywhere from 2-18 hours, sometimes in heated tumblers, and sometimes just in climate controlled rooms. During this process, the tea begins to break down inside and release key elements of its flavour. It will also begin to change colour from green to brown. But, not all teas will be fully, or even semi-oxidised...

Fermenting

Some teas, such as puer teas from Yunnan, go through a fermentation phase. This is different from oxidisation, and produces different flavours. Fermentation is also a much longer process, happening without the influence of air (whereas oxidisation involves regularly changing the air).

Shaping

An important part of tea-making is to shape the leaves. One facet of the Chinese art of tea-making is the appreciation of different leaf shapes and patterns. In this stage, a tea master will use a variety of techniques to roll, press and shape the tea into spirals or ball shapes that enhance the natural taste of the tea.

Fixing

Once a tea has reached the right stage of oxidisation, just like a photograph it must be fixed. Normally a tea is fixed by applying high heat for a short period, which stops the oxidisation process.

Roasting

Depending on the type of tea, roasting is optional - for example, green teas are often not roasted, whereas black teas are fully roasted.

Variations

There are many subtle variations on this theme for producing different teas. Different equipment can be used, different techniques or materials can produce unique tastes, and even some teas like our Jasmine Pearls can be flavoured with the addition of jasmine flowers in the final stages.

fields.title: Culture
fields.content: Tea culture in China has been practised for thousands of years. There's a myriad of ceremonies, uses and meanings for tea, and we'll try to help you get to grips with them!

fields.title: Benefits
fields.content:
The health benefits of drinking tea are widely quoted, but not conclusive. We'll try to give you a balanced view on the health and lifestyle benefits of drinking good quality Chinese teas.

Health claims

One of the biggest reasons people look for traditional Chinese teas is for health. While we believe it's part of a healthy lifestyle, we'd also encourage our customers to drink tea because you enjoy it, rather than because you expect some miraculous health benefits.

  • Check out the UK Tea Advisory Panel for independent health advice related to tea
  • Cancer Research UK also carries some useful balanced information on their website.
  • A useful summary of US FDA requirements for nutrition labelling of tea products from www.lawoftea.com

Serious long-term studies of tea-drinking are inconclusive on humans - most studies investigating the benefits of drinking tea on cardiovascular health, heart disease and weight loss show that there are benefits, but they are not consistent in human trials. Similarly, different types of tea contain different chemicals, and will have different effects.

Caffeine

Caffeine levels in tea are generally lower than coffee - roughly half-to-1/3rd of a cup of coffee. Green tea carries less caffeine (in the cup) than black tea. However, it is still a caffeinated drink, and anecdotal evidence suggests it's quite easy to become 'tea drunk', especially when drinking small cups in rapid succession (eg. in the traditional Chinese way).

Weight loss

Many teas are hailed as miracle 'weight loss' or skinny teas. Although medical trials have shown some effects of tea in helping to oxidise fat in the body, its not proven. Drinking tea with a large helping of milk and sugar might actually negate any positive effects! However, if you're making the switch from sugary soft drinks to tea, as part of a generally more healthy diet, then we believe this is a positive step.

Other medical benefits

Tea is credited by some to have a positive effect on cancer, multiple sclerosis, removing 'smokers cough' and many other things. The scientific evidence for this doesn't conclude this, and our advice, as always, is to take any claims with a pinch of salt - drink tea because you enjoy the taste.

Medicinal tea blends

It's common in Chinese culture to call any hot herbal preparation a 'tea'. For example, in summer many restaurants in southern China will serve liang cha (cool tea) to help rehydrate and cool the body. But this liang cha isn't made with tea, but a mix of natural herbs and roots. We don't sell any of these preparations, but always be careful when buying medicinal 'tea' blends and check whether they actually contain tea at all.

fields.title: How to brew Lapsang Souchong
fields.content:
Lapsang souchong (zheng shan xiao zhong) is a black tea, and so you can get stuck straight in with boiling water - 1-2 minutes steep is all you'll need.

You'll need a big 3-finger pinch of tea per person, and feel free to brew this tea in a teapot or in your cup.

A good Lapsang has thin, rolled dry leaves which appear brittle. When wet, they will unfurl slightly, revealing a muddy-red colour and smooth texture. The aroma is most commonly described as 'campfire' and/or 'bonfire' - although you'll smell the traditional smokey pinewood, you should also pick up some natural plum and berry notes as well.

Lapsang is pretty flexible when it comes to temperature - use boiling water if you like that hard smokey edge, or ease off and use 80-90 degree water if you prefer the fruity undertones. Rebrew 3-4 times at least.

fields.title: How to brew Old Iron
fields.content:
Old Iron is a roasted oolong tea, and should be brewed with slightly off-the-boil water (around 90 degrees) for roughly 1-2 minutes.

Oolong teas are partly oxidised, and so need a slightly gentler touch when it comes to water temperature - give the kettle a minute to cool before you pour.

As the tea infuses, you'll smell a heady mix of natural vegetal tea leaves, and a deeper roasted taste common to red teas. The liquor will not be green or red - more like a rich yellow colour.

Brew in the teapot or directly in your mug - you'll need around 4g per person, which is a big three finger pinch of dry leaves. Rebrew 3-4 times, lengthening the steeping time slightly each time.

fields.title: How to brew Jin Jun Mei
fields.content:
Jin Jun Mei is a very high quality roasted red tea - slightly off-the-boil water and a short steep time (1-2 minutes) will be perfect.

Jin Jun Mei is made using only young tea shoots (typically a pair of 2 young shoots together). The dry leaves will appear thin and wiry - in fact, the smaller the leaves, normally the better quality the tea.

The overall aroma has 'forest' themes. It's woody, and yet carries a strong natural sweetness as well - plums, red dates and hazel. The liquor will be slightly syrupy, with a deep auburn colour.

A tea this fine should really be brewed in a traditional gai wan but it will also do fine in a teapot or mug. Take a big 3-finger pinch per person, and remember to rebrew the leaves 3-4 times.

Our expert tip for this tea - it's actually a fairly dusty tea, so if you have the time, wash the leaves first. Just pour a small amount of hot water over the leaves, swill and then drain the liquid to get rid of the tea dust.

fields.title: The Knowledge (All About Tea)
fields.content: Chinese tea has been cultivated and grown in China for over 3000 years - here you'll find general information about tea culture, cultivation and background.

fields.meta_description: Lapsang Souchong is a black tea from the mountain areas around Wuyi Shan in the Fujian Province - one of the most famous areas for red teas in China.
fields.title: Where is Lapsang Souchong grown?
fields.content:
Our Lapsang Souchong Chinese tea is grown and processed near Wuyi Mountain in the Fujian Province.

Lapsang Souchong is grown near Wuyi Mountain (wuyi shan), one of the most famous red tea growing regions in China. The mountain is around 4 hours away from the coast, and a huge variety of red/black teas are grown around here, like our Jin Jun Mei, The Big Red and Lapsang Souchong teas.

fields.title: About Min River Tea (China)
fields.content: Min River Tea is a worldwide tea company selling exceptional loose-leaf Chinese teas. We were established in 2010 in the UK, and now we sell to customers as far and wide as Australia, South Africa, America and China itself.

fields.title: Shipping (China)
fields.content:
We ship anywhere in China, using express, registered delivery, door-to-door services.

We ship our teas to any part of China you happen to live in. Delivery is always using Express Delivery services, which are trackable and fast.

Delivery times may vary, but are normally within 1-3 working days. Teas are shipped from Fuzhou, Fujian, and so customers living in Western China or in more remote countryside areas may experience slightly longer delivery times.
